I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker
DECISION
Dear Sir/Madam, 
On July 17, 2025, you filed a Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker, to classify the
beneficiary under section 101(a)(15)(O)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (the Act).
Section 101(a)(15)(O) of the Act defines an alien of extraordinary ability as: 
an alien who-- 
(i) has extraordinary ability in the sciences, arts, education, business, or athletics which
has been demonstrated by sustained national or international acclaim or, with regard to
motion picture and television productions a demonstrated record of extraordinary
achievement, and whose achievements have been recognized in the field through
extensive documentation, and seeks to enter the United States to continue work in the
area of extraordinary ability; ... 
Title 8 Code of Federal Regulations (8 CFR), section 214.2(o)(3)(ii) states:            
Extraordinary ability in the field of science, education, business, or athletics means a level of
expertise indicating that the person is one of the small percentage who have arisen to the very
top of the field of endeavor. 
Your Petition
You are a talent agency that was established in 2024.  You currently employ two individuals.  In your
petition you claim that you seek to employ the beneficiary as a "world class combat sports athlete" for
a period of three years at the salary of $250,000 per year.
The initial record did not establish the necessary requirements, including:
Copies of written contracts between the petitioner and the alien beneficiary or, if there is no
written contract, a summary of the terms of the oral agreement under which the alien(s) will be

Your response, received on September 8, 2025, includes the following evidence:

U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services' (USCIS) decision in a particular case is dependent upon
the quality of the evidence submitted by you, the petitioner, not just the quantity of the evidence.  The
fact that you have submitted evidence of either a qualifying award or evidence relating to at least three
of the applicable criteria as required by the regulation does not necessarily establish that the
beneficiary is eligible for O-1 classification.  The evidence submitted must establish that the
beneficiary qualifies as an individual of extraordinary ability.  See 59 Fed. Reg. 41818, 41820 (Aug.
15, 1994) (“The evidence submitted by the petitioner is not the standard for the classification, but
merely the mechanism to establish whether the standard has been met.”). 
The standard for the classification relates to the definition of the classification. The totality of the
evidence must establish that the beneficiary has sustained national or international acclaim and is one
of the small percentage who have arisen to the very top of the beneficiary's field. 
The record does not establish the necessary requirements, including:
At the time of filing, the record included a summary of the terms of the oral agreement under
which the alien will be employed as required by 8 CFR section 214.2(o)(2)(ii)(B);
An explanation of the nature of the events or activities, the beginning and ending dates for the
events or activities; and a copy of any itinerary for the events or activities as required by 8 CFR
section 214.2(o)(2)(ii)(C);
A written advisory opinion(s) from the appropriate consulting entity or entities as required by 8
CFR section 214.2(o)(2)(ii)(D); and
At the time of filing, you satisfied all of the conditions for filing as a: 
U.S. agent filing the petition on behalf of a foreign employer as defined in 8 CFR
214.2(o)(2)(iv)(E)(3).
All deficiencies in the record will be further discussed below. 
General Requirements

Title 8 CFR 214.2(o)(2)(ii) identifies the general documentary evidence required to accompany a
petition filed for O aliens as:
(A) The evidence specified in the particular section for the classification;
(B) Copies of any written contracts between the petitioner and the alien beneficiary or, if there
is no written contract, a summary of the terms of the oral agreement under which the alien will
be employed;
(C) An explanation of the nature of the events or activities, the beginning and ending dates for
the events or activities; and a copy of any itinerary for the events or activities; and
(D) A written advisory opinion(s) from the appropriate consulting entity or entities.
Contracts
The first issue is whether you have satisfied the contract requirement.
Title 8 CFR 214.2(o)(2)(ii)(B) requires copies of any written contracts between the petitioner and the
alien beneficiary or, if there is no written contract, a summary of the terms of the oral agreement under
which the alien(s) will be employed.
In addition,  8 CFR 103.2(b)(1) states:
(b) Evidence and processing
(1) Demonstrating eligibility. An applicant or petitioner must establish that he or she is
eligible for the requested benefit at the time of filing the benefit request and must
continue to be eligible through adjudication. Each benefit request must be properly
completed and filed with all initial evidence required by applicable regulations and other
USCIS instructions. Any evidence submitted in connection with a benefit request is
incorporated into and considered part of the request.
USCIS recognized in the RFE your submission of a letter of support as well as a "Petitioner and
Talent Agreement" and between you and the beneficiary. However, the RFE notified you that the
document includes conflicting information relating to the relationship between you, the beneficiary,
and the employers who seek to hire the beneficiary for services rendered.
For example, in your petition support letter you state:
The Petitioner is acting on behalf of the Beneficiary, a foreign-based self-employed
professional athlete and entrepreneur, to coordinate a variety of extraordinary engagements
across the United States. These engagements include participation in high-profile mixed martial
arts competitions, promotional appearances, media productions, sponsorship activations, and
leadership initiatives through his role with the Professional Fighters League (PFL).
The RFE explained that the scenario described above is indicative of a U.S. agent representing the
beneficiary and his multiple employers. Additionally, your petition support letter states:
2. Service of Process:

The RFE explained that, regardless of the capacity in which you are filing the instant petition, the
evidence submitted with your petition did not satisfy the contract requirement.  The "Petition and
Talent Agreement" between you and the beneficiary is insufficient to satisfy the contract requirement
because this document does not sufficiently detail the terms and conditions under which the
beneficiary will be employed.
For example, the initially submitted "Petition and Talent Agreement" indicates the beneficiary will
earn $250,000 per year "in wages and competition earnings". You also stated that these wages are
"subject to such adjustments as may be determined by applicable parties from time to time".
 Therefore, the beneficiary's initially claimed annual earnings appeared to be speculative. The initial
record did not contain contracts, establishing the wage offered to the beneficiary and details regarding
the terms and conditions between the beneficiary and the "applicable parties" who seek to hire the
beneficiary for services rendered.
In response to the RFE you provided a "US Agent Representation Agreement" between the newly
identified foreign employer, Boza Investment SARL, and you, the U.S. agent.  This agreement signed
by both parties and the beneficiary on September 4, 2025, describes the employment relationship
between the beneficiary and Boza Investment.  The agreement states that the employment period is
September 1, 2025 through August 31, 2026, "with automatic renewal provisions".  
Regarding the beneficiary's compensation for his employment, the "US Agent Representation
Agreement" states the beneficiary will now earn a "minimum $30,000 USD per month ($360,000
annually), paid via direct wire transfer from Foreign Employer's business accounts".
However, the evidence submitted with your response to the RFE does not establish that, at the time
you filed the instant petition, your petition included a contract detailing the actual terms and conditions
of the beneficiary's employment during the requested validity period.  For example, the RFE response
identifies a new foreign employer and the "US Agent Representation Agreement" includes a
significant change in the beneficiary's compensation from $250,000 per year to $360,000 per year. The

significant change in the beneficiary's compensation from $250,000 per year to $360,000 per year. The
inconsistencies between the two agreements call into question the veracity of the information
provided "Petitioner and Talent Agreement" that was submitted with your petition.
In addition, in your initial petition you requested an employment start date of July 1, 2025, and, as
explained above, the "US Agent Representation Agreement" indicates an employment start of
September 1, 2025, and the "US Agent Representation Agreement" was signed by all parties on
September 4, 2025. Both dates indicate the "US Agent Representation Agreement" was entered into
after the date you filed the instant petition and after the issuance of the RFE.  
As explained above, in 8 CFR 103.2(b) a  petitioner must establish eligibility for the requested benefit
at the time of filing the benefit request.  Further, in is noted in Matter of Michelin Tire Corp., 17 I&N
Dec. 248 (Comm.1978),  the the petitioner must establish eligibility at the time of filing the visa
petition.  A visa petition may not be approved at a future date after the petitioner or beneficiary
becomes eligible under a new set of facts. 
Moreover, the newly claim employment relationship between the beneficiary and his foreign
employer, Boza Investment, as well as the changes in wages earned by the beneficiary appears to be a
material change in the the terms and conditions of the beneficiary's employment.  A petitioner may not
make material corrections to his petition in an effort to make a deficient petition conform to USCIS
requirements. Matter of Izummi, 22 I&N Dec. 169 (Comm. 1998).
Considering the discussion above, the record does not establish the terms and conditions of the
beneficiary's employment as claimed in the "US Agent Representation Agreement" existed at the time
you filed the instant petition.  Further, the evidence of record does not establish that the information
contained in the Petitioner and Talent Agreement are an accurate representation of the beneficiary's
employment during the requested validity period. As such, your petition does not satisfy the
requirements of 8 CFR 214.2(o)(2)(ii)(B).

When there are inconsistencies in the record, it is the responsibility of the petitioner to resolve any
such inconsistencies by using independent, objective evidence.  Any attempt to explain or reconcile
such inconsistencies will not suffice unless the petitioner submits competent objective evidence
pointing to where the truth lies.  See Matter of Ho, 19 I&N Dec. 582 (BIA 1988).  The record does not

the "Comprehensive Business Operations Itinerary" and "US Agent Representation Agreement" and to
establish the nature of the beneficiary's event as a "world class combat sports athlete".

employment as required by 8 CFR 214.2(o)(2)(ii)(C) have not been established.  
Consultation
The third issue is whether your petition includes an advisory opinion from a U.S. peer group, labor
organization, and/or management organization in the area of the beneficiary’s ability.
Title 8 CFR 214.2(o)(5)(i) states in pertinent part: 
(A) Consultation with an appropriate U.S. peer group (which could include a person or persons
with expertise in the field), labor, and/or management organization regarding the nature of the
work to be done and the alien's qualifications is mandatory before a petition for an O-1 or O-2
classification can be approved.
(B) Except as provided in paragraph (o)(5)(i)(E) of this section, evidence of consultation shall
be in the form of a written advisory opinion from a peer group (which could include a person or
persons with expertise in the field), labor, and/or management organization.
(C) Except as provided in paragraph (o)(5)(i)(E) of this section, the petitioner shall obtain a
written advisory opinion from a peer group (which could include a person or persons with
expertise in the field), labor, and/or management organization with expertise in the specific field
involved.  The advisory opinion shall be submitted along with the petition when the petition is
filed.  The advisory opinion should set forth a specific statement of facts which supports the
conclusion reached in the opinion.  Advisory opinions must be submitted in writing and must
be signed by an authorized official of the group or organization.
(D) Except as provided in paragraph (o)(5)(i)(E) and (G) of this section, written evidence of
consultation shall be included in the record of every approved O petition.  Consultations are
advisory and are not binding on the Service.         
...
(F) In routine processing case where the petition is accompanied by a written opinion from a
peer group, but the peer group is not a labor organization, the Director will forward a copy of
petition and all supporting documentation to the national office of the appropriate labor
organization within 5 days of receipt of the petition...

(G) In those cases where it is established by the petitioner that an appropriate peer group,

Petitions seeking O-1A nonimmigrant classification must include a written advisory opinion from a
U.S. peer group, labor organization, and/or management organization in the area of the beneficiary’s
ability.  The U.S. peer group may include a person or persons with expertise in the field.
In your petition, you indicated on the O and P Classifications Supplement and/or in the record that an
appropriate labor organization does not exist for this position.  
The RFE notified you that a review of the record found no letter from a U.S. peer group in the area of
the beneficiary’s ability or documentation that an appropriate peer group does not exist.
In response to the RFE you provided statement explaining why there is no appropriate labor
organization for a World Class Combat Sports Athlete".  While there does not appear to be a labor
organization for combat sports, you did not submit a letter from a U.S. peer group or evidence that a
U.S. peer group does not exist in combat sports.
Therefore, your petition does not satisfy 8 CFR 214.2(o)(5)(i) because your petition is not
accompanied by an advisory opinion from a U.S. peer group and the record does not contain
documentary evidence that a U.S. peer group does not exist in combat sports.
Agent Petitioner
The fourth issue is that you have not satisfied the requirements for an agent as petitioner.
Title 8 CFR 214.2(o)(2)(i) provides a general discussion about the filing of O petitions and states in
pertinent part: 
...An O-1 or O-2 petition may only be filed by a United States employer, a United States agent,
or a foreign employer through a United States agent.  For purposes of paragraph (o) of this
section, a foreign employer is any employer who is not amenable to service of process in the
United States.  A foreign employer may not directly petition for an O nonimmigrant alien but
instead must use the services of a United States agent to file a petition for an O nonimmigrant
alien.  A United States agent petitioning on behalf of a foreign employer must be authorized to
file the petition, and to accept services of process in the United States in proceedings under
section 274A of the Act, on behalf of the foreign employer... 
Furthermore, 8 CFR 214.2(o)(2)(iv)(E) discusses agents as petitioners and states: 
A United States agent may file a petition in cases involving workers who are traditionally
self-employed or workers who use agents to arrange short-term employment on their behalf
with numerous employers, and in cases where a foreign employer authorizes the agent to act in
its behalf.  A United States agent may be:  The actual employer of the beneficiary, the
representative of both the employer and the beneficiary; or, a person or entity authorized by the
employer to act for, or in place of, the employer as its agent.  A petition filed by an agent is
subject to the following conditions: 
An agent performing the function of an employer must provide the contractual
agreement between the agent and the beneficiary which specifies the wage offered and

Agent for Foreign Employer
A foreign employer who, through a U.S. agent, files a petition for a O nonimmigrant alien is

In your petition support letter you also stated that you are a U.S. agent and seek to "accept service of
process on behalf of the Beneficiary and Foreign Employer if applicable".  However, the initial
petition did not identify any foreign employers who have contracted the beneficiary's services as a

foreign employer such as how the beneficiary will be paid, etc. For example, the  "Petitioner and

annually.  However, the initial record did not include documentation relating to how or by whom the
beneficiary will be paid.
As such, the initial evidence of record did not specify the wage offered by a foreign employer and

did not establish that you are authorized to file the instant petition and to accept service of process on
behalf of a foreign employer. Therefore, initial record did not establish that you are a U.S. agent filing
on behalf of a foreign employer.

beneficiary on September 4, 2025, describes the employment relationship between the beneficiary and

August 31, 2026, "with automatic renewal provisions".  
USCIS acknowledges that you provided corporate documentation for Boza Investment showing that
the beneficiary is the sole shareholder/associate of the company and was registered in April 26, 2024;
however, there appears to be a significant changes in the "US Agent Representation Agreement" that
calls into question whether Boza Investment was the intended employer in your initial petition.

For example, regarding the beneficiary's compensation for his employment, the "US Agent
Representation Agreement" states the beneficiary will now earn a "minimum $30,000 USD per month
($360,000 annually), paid via direct wire transfer from Foreign Employer's business accounts".  This
wage amount is a significant change in the beneficiary's compensation from $250,000 per year to
$360,000 per year. 
In addition, as explained above. your initial petition requested an employment start date of July 1,
2025, and the newly submitted "US Agent Representation Agreement" indicates an employment start
of September 1, 2025.  Moreover, the "US Agent Representation Agreement" was signed by all parties
on September 4, 2025.  Both dates indicate the "US Agent Representation Agreement" was entered
into after the date you filed the instant petition and after the issuance of the RFE. 
As explained above, in 8 CFR 103.2(b) a  petitioner must establish eligibility for the requested benefit
at the time of filing the benefit request.  Further, it is noted in Matter of Michelin Tire Corp. the the
petitioner must establish eligibility at the time of filing the visa petition.  A visa petition may not be
approved at a future date after the petitioner or beneficiary becomes eligible under a new set of facts. 
Moreover, the newly claim employment relationship between the beneficiary and his foreign
employer, Boza Investment, as well as the changes in wages earned by the beneficiary appears to be a
material change in the the terms and conditions of the beneficiary's employment.  A petitioner may not
make material corrections to his petition in an effort to make a deficient petition conform to USCIS
requirements. see Matter of Izummi.
Considering the discussion above, the evidence of record does not establish that you satisfied the
conditions for a U.S. agent filing on behalf of a foreign employer as defined in 8 CFR
214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E)(3).
Conclusion
In view of the above, the record does not establish:
The record does not establish the necessary requirements, including:
At the time of filing, the record included a summary of the terms of the oral agreement under
which the alien will be employed as required by 8 CFR section 214.2(o)(2)(ii)(B);
An explanation of the nature of the events or activities, the beginning and ending dates for the
events or activities; and a copy of any itinerary for the events or activities as required by 8 CFR
section 214.2(o)(2)(ii)(C);
A written advisory opinion(s) from the appropriate consulting entity or entities as required by 8
CFR section 214.2(o)(2)(ii)(D); and
At the time of filing, you satisfied all of the conditions for filing as a: 
U.S. agent filing the petition on behalf of a foreign employer as defined in 8 CFR
214.2(o)(2)(iv)(E)(3).
As such, the evidence of record does not establish that the beneficiary qualifies as an O-1A
nonimmigrant under section 101(a)(15)(O)(i) of the Act. 
Therefore, your petition is denied. 
If applicable, the portion of the petition requesting an extension of stay or change of status for the
beneficiary is now being denied as the nonimmigrant visa petition filed on the beneficiary's behalf has

I-129 O-1A Extraordinary Ability in Science, Education, Business, or Athletics
You, Innovative Global Talent Agency LLC, filed Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker,
seeking O-1A nonimmigrant classification for Francis Ngannou as World Class Combat Sports Athlete.
The O-1A classification applies to individuals with extraordinary ability in the sciences, education,
business, or athletics.  The individual must have sustained national or international acclaim.  The
individual's achievements must be in the field of expertise and show that the individual is one of a
small percentage who has risen to the very top of the field.  The individual must be coming to the
United States to continue work in the individual's area of extraordinary ability.
Pursuant to the preponderance of evidence standard, USCIS will examine each piece of evidence for
relevance, probative value, and credibility, both individually and within the context of the totality of
evidence, to determine whether the fact to be proven is probably true.  USCIS comprehensively
reviews the entire body of evidence before rendering a final determination of eligibility.  Upon review
of the evidence you submitted in the initial filing, the record contains insufficient documentation to
establish the beneficiary meets the regulatory requirements for the O-1A classification. 
To process your petition and determine if the beneficiary is eligible, additional information is
required.  This request provides suggested evidence that you may submit to satisfy each requested
item.  You may:
Submit one, some, or all of these items;
Submit none of the suggested items and instead submit other evidence to satisfy the request;
Explain how the evidence in the record already establishes eligibility; and/or
Request a decision based on the record. 
Note, however, that you are responsible for providing evidence that best shows that you and the parties
to this petition meet all requirements.  Evidence must show that all parties were eligible for the
requested benefit when you filed Form I-129.
Note: When submitting additional evidence, please indicate to which individual criterion it applies.  If
you choose to submit comparable evidence in lieu of one or more of the criteria below, please indicate
why the criteria you wish to replace do not apply to the occupation.  
Additionally, when submitting articles, internet abstracts, and other documentation (excluding
testimonial letters) that includes the beneficiary’s name, please highlight the beneficiary’s name.  
Please submit evidence that is the most current and is presented in an orderly fashion. Illegible
photocopies will not be accepted as valid evidence.

includes any documents you submit in response to this Request for Evidence.  In order for USCIS to
consider this evidence, you must submit English language translations for each document.  The
translator must certify that:
The translations are accurate and complete; and
The translator is competent to translate from the foreign language into English.

General Requirements for All O-1A Nonimmigrant Petitions 
In general, petitions seeking O nonimmigrant classification must include: 
Copies of contracts;
A description of the competition(s), event(s), or performance(s); and
At least one consultation. 
To satisfy these requirements, you submitted:
A letter of support; and
A "Petitioner and Talent Agreement". 
Contracts
Petitions seeking O nonimmigrant classification must include a copy of a contract between the
beneficiary and either the petitioner or the employer.  If a written contract does not exist, you may
submit a detailed summary of the terms of the oral agreement between the beneficiary and either the
petitioner or the employer.  
The contract you submitted is insufficient.
USCIS recognizes your submission of a letter of support as well as a "Petitioner and Talent
Agreement" and between you and the beneficiary. However, this document includes conflicting
information relating to the relationship between you, the beneficiary, and the employers who seek to
hire the beneficiary for services rendered.

professional athlete and entrepreneur, to coordinate a variety of extraordinary engagements
across the United States. These engagements include participation in high-profile mixed martial
arts competitions, promotional appearances, media productions, sponsorship activations, and
leadership initiatives through his role with the Professional Fighters League (PFL).
The above the scenario described is indicative of a U.S. agent representing the beneficiary and his
multiple employers.
Additionally, your petition support letter states:
2. Service of Process:

The Petitioner acts as a U.S. Agent representing a self-employed foreign employer. This

Title 8 CFR 214.2(o)(2)(iv)(E) discusses agents as petitioners and states:
A United States agent may file a petition in cases involving workers who are traditionally
self-employed or workers who use agents to arrange short-term employment on their behalf
with numerous employers, and in cases where a foreign employer authorizes the agent to act in
its behalf. A United States agent may be: The actual employer of the beneficiary, the
representative of both the employer and the beneficiary; or, a person or entity authorized by the
employer to act for, or in place of, the employer as its agent. A petition filed by an agent is
subject to the following conditions:
(1) An agent performing the function of an employer must provide the contractual
agreement between the agent and the beneficiary which specifies the wage offered and
the other terms and conditions of employment of the beneficiary.
(2) A person or company in business as an agent may file the petition involving multiple
employers as the representative of both the employers and the beneficiary, if supporting
documentation includes a complete itinerary of the event or events. The itinerary must
specify the dates of each service or engagement, the names and addresses of the actual
employers, and the names and addresses of the establishments, venues, or locations
where the services will be performed. A contract between the employers and the
beneficiary is required. The burden is on the agent to explain the terms and conditions of
the employment and to provide any required documentation.
(3) A foreign employer who, through a United States agent, files a petition for an O

DECISION
Dear Sir/Madam, 
On May 15, 2025, you filed a Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker, to classify the
beneficiary as an athlete under section 101(a)(15)(P)(i)(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act
(Act).
Section 214(c)(4)(A) of the Act states that for the purposes of section 101(a)(15)(P)(i)(a), an alien is
described in this subparagraph if the alien-
(i)(I) performs as an athlete, individually or as part of a group or team, at an internationally
recognized level of performance;
(II) is a professional athlete, as defined in section 204(i)(2);
(III) performs as an athlete, or as a coach, as part of a team or franchise that is located in the

Title 8 Code of Federal Regulations (8 CFR), section 214.2(p)(1)(ii)(A) states:
A P-1 classification applies to an alien who is coming temporarily to the United
States:
To perform at a specific athletic competition as an athlete, individually or as part of a
group or team, at an internationally recognized level of performance, or
1.
To perform with, or as an integral and essential part of the performance of, an
entertainment group that has been recognized internationally as being outstanding in
the discipline for a sustained and substantial period of time, and who has had a
sustained and substantial relationship with the group (ordinarily for at least 1 year)
and provides functions integral to the performance of the group.
2.
Further, 8 CFR section 214.2(p)(2)(ii) states:  
Evidence required to accompany a petition for a P nonimmigrant.  Petitions for P
nonimmigrant aliens shall be accompanied by the following:

which the alien(s) will be employed;
B.

dates for the events or activities, and a copy of any itinerary for the events or
activities; and
C.
A written consultation from a labor organization.D.

General.  A P-1 athlete must have an internationally recognized reputation as an international
athlete or he or she must be a member of a foreign team that is internationally recognized.  The
athlete or team must be coming to the United States to participate in an athletic competition
which has a distinguished reputation and which requires participation of an athlete or athletic
team that has an international reputation.

competition which has a distinguished reputation and which requires participation of an athlete
or athletic team that has an international reputation.

Lastly, 8 CFR 214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E) states: 
Agents as petitioners.  A United States agent may file a petition in cases involving workers who
are traditionally self-employed or workers who use agents to arrange short-term employment
on their behalf with numerous employers, and in cases where a foreign employer authorizes the
agent to act on its behalf.  A United States agent may be: the actual employer of the
beneficiary; the representative of both the employer and the beneficiary; or, a person or entity
authorized by the employer to act for, or in place of, the employer as its agent.  A petition filed
by an United States agent is subject to the following conditions: 
(1) An agent performing the function of an employer must specify the wage offered and
the other terms and conditions of employment by contractual agreement with the
beneficiary or beneficiaries. The agent/employer must also provide an itinerary of
definite employment and information on any other services planned for the period of
time requested.
(2) A person or company in business as an agent may file the P petition involving
multiple employers as the representative of both the employers and the beneficiary or
beneficiaries if the supporting documentation includes a complete itinerary of services or
engagements. The itinerary shall specify the dates of each service or engagement, the
names and addresses of the actual employers, the names and addresses of the
establishment, venues, or locations where the services will be performed. In questionable
cases, a contract between the employer(s) and the beneficiary or beneficiaries may be
required. The burden is on the agent to explain the terms and conditions of the
employment and to provide any required documentation.

evidence (RFE) requesting additional documentation to overcome the deficiencies in the record.   
On August 18, 2025, USCIS received your response.  The record does not establish the beneficiary
qualifies for the P-1A classification.  All deficiencies in the record will be further discussed below.
Prior Approvals
USCIS acknowledges that the beneficiary has previously been granted the benefit being sought, that
you are requesting to extend your petition and have requested USCIS grant deference to prior
approvals when evaluating the beneficiary's eligibility for the benefit being sought.  When
adjudicating a subsequent petition or application involving the same parties and the same underlying
facts, where appropriate, USCIS will generally defer to its prior determination of eligibility for the
particular nonimmigrant classification sought.
However, each petition filing is a separate proceeding with a separate record.  Despite any previously
approved petitions, the petitioner bears the burden to establish eligibility for each petition that it
submits, and an immigration benefit cannot be granted when the petitioner fails to meet its burden of
proof for the petition it files, including an extension petition. See INA § 291.  USCIS is not required to
approve petitions where eligibility has not been demonstrated, merely because of prior approvals
which may have been erroneous.  Matter of Church Scientology International, 19 I&N Dec. 593, 597
(Comm'r 1988).
USCIS will not defer to prior approvals where:
There was a material error with regard to the previous approval(s);  1.
There has been a material change in circumstances or eligibility requirements; or  2.
There is new material information that adversely impacts the petitioner’s, beneficiary’s, or
applicant’s eligibility.
3.
USCIS recognizes your petition includes statements and supporting evidence referencing the
beneficiary’s prior approvals for the requested classification.  USCIS has reviewed this instant petition
filed on behalf of the beneficiary.  There has been a material change in circumstances or eligibility
requirements.  On Form I-129 Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker, your requested filing
classification indicates there is a "Change of Employer".  Therefore, there has been a material change
in circumstances or eligibility requirements. 
Additionally, you have not established the requirements for agent petitioners as described under 8
CFR 214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E).
As such, there is new material information that adversely impacts the petitioner’s, beneficiaries’, or
applicant’s eligibility.  Additionally, if the same or similar evidence was submitted with the
beneficiaries’ prior approvals, there was a material error with regard to the previous approval(s).
As stated above, despite any previously approved petitions, the petitioner bears the burden to establish
eligibility for each petition that it submits, and an immigration benefit cannot be granted when the
petitioner fails to meet its burden of proof for the petition it files, including an extension petition.
Therefore, this petition must be supported by its own documentation and will be adjudicated based
upon its own merits.  A more detailed discussion about the deficiencies will be discussed below. 
USCIS will not defer to its prior approval in adjudicating this petition.

the beneficiary; the representative of both the employer and the beneficiary; or, a person or
entity authorized by the employer to act for, or in place of, the employer as its agent. A petition
filed by an United States agent is subject to the following conditions:
(1) An agent performing the function of an employer must specify the wage offered and
the other terms and conditions of employment by contractual agreement with the
beneficiary or beneficiaries. The agent/employer must also provide an itinerary of
definite employment and information on any other services planned for the period of

names and addresses of the actual employers, the names and addresses of the

to participate in an athletic competition or league that has a distinguished reputation and which requires

Tendered Contract
In accordance with 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii), the evidence in the record must include a tendered contract
with a major United States sports league or team, or a tendered contract in an individual sport
commensurate with international recognition in that sport, if such contracts are normally executed in
the sport.
As stated above, the included itinerary states the following:

This itinerary and the supporting evidence demonstrate that the athlete’s participation is required at
internationally recognized competitions, satisfying a key requirement for P-1A visa classification.
Your statements indicate that to participate in the listed competitions on the included itinerary, an
"Official Invitation/Registration: Formal documentation confirming acceptance or invitation to
compete" is required to compete and also there is a "Contract/Agreement: Documentation of
agreements to participate in specified competitions" which is signed prior to participation. 
You submitted no contracts with the organizing bodies or official invites to any of the listed
competitions.  
The record does not include a tendered contract with a major United States sports league or team, or a
tendered contract in an individual sport commensurate with international recognition in that sport, if
such contracts are normally executed in the sport.
Beneficiary Qualifications
You indicate the beneficiary qualifies for P-1 non-immigrant status.  As defined in statute and
regulation, a beneficiary may qualify for the P-1A classification as an internationally recognized
athlete, a professional athlete, an amateur athlete, or as a professional or amateur skater who performs
individually or as part of a group in a theatrical ice skating production.  
As you do not claim the beneficiary qualifies as a professional athlete, an amateur athlete, or a
professional or amateur skater who performs individually or as a part of a group in a theatrical ice
skating production these grounds of eligibility will not be discussed further in this denial.
Requirements for Athletes and Teams
You indicate that the beneficiary or team has international recognition.  In this situation, the P-1A
classification requires an athlete to have an internationally recognized reputation.  Alternatively, an
athlete must be a member of a foreign team that is internationally recognized in the sport.  The athlete
or team must be coming to the United States solely to participate in competitions that have
distinguished reputations.  Petitions for:
1.  Individual athletes, competing as individuals or on a U.S. team, must show the
international recognition is based on their individual accomplishments and that the services to

be performed require an internationally recognized athlete
2.  A team must show that it has achieved international recognition and that the services to be
performed require an internationally recognized athletic team.  Each member of the team then
receives P-1A classification based on the team’s recognition.
P1A International Athlete Discussion
International Athlete
Based on the evidence provided, you are seeking to qualify the beneficiary as an internationally
recognized athlete.  The international athlete must perform as an athlete, individually or as part of a
group or team, at an internationally recognized level of performance.  You must establish the
beneficiary or team’s eligibility under at least two of the seven criteria set forth in 8 CFR
214.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2).  Each criterion will be discussed separately. 
First Criterion
To meet the first criterion, at 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2)(i), you must submit evidence the beneficiary
participated to a significant extent in a prior season with a major United States sports league. 
Your support letter states the following regarding the beneficiary’s eligibility under this criterion:
Jeremiah Elie clearly meets the regulatory requirement under 8 CFR 21 4.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2)(i)
through significant participation in major United States-based international sporting events.
Specifically, he has prominently participated in internationally recognized competitions within
the United States, including the prestigious Arnold Amateur USA, which consistently attracts
top-tier global competitors.
Moreover, your letter also states:
The Beneficiary, Jeremiah Elie, has previously been approved under the P-1A visa
classification and has consistently maintained continuous activity in professional bodybuilding
and fitness competitions at the highest international levels. While professional bodybuilding
does not follow a traditional team sports league structure like the NFL or NBA, it is
prominently recognized and structured through major sanctioned international competitions
under renowned governing bodies such as the International Federation of Bodybuilding and
Fitness (IFBB).
Per your own statements, "bodybuilding does not follow a traditional team sports league structure like
the NFL or NBA".  To meet the plain language of this requirement, you must submit
evidence showing participation in a prior season with a major U.S. sports league.  While you submitted
evidence that the beneficiary has participated in various bodybuilding competitions, the submitted
evidence does not establish that the beneficiary participated in a prior season with a major U.S. sports
league.  
You have not submitted sufficient evidence that the beneficiary participated to a significant extent in a
prior season with a major United States sports league.  Accordingly, you have not established that the
beneficiary meets this criterion.
Second Criterion
To meet the second criterion, at 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2)(ii), you must submit evidence the
beneficiary participated in international competition with a national team. 
Your included support letter states the following:

USCIS recognizes your submission of various documents listing the results of competitions in which

You have not submitted sufficient evidence that the beneficiary participated in international
competition with a national team.  Accordingly, you have not established that the beneficiary meets
this criterion.
Third Criterion
To meet the third criterion, at 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2)(iii), you must submit evidence the
beneficiary participated to a significant extent in a prior season for a United States college or
university in intercollegiate competition. 
You do not claim that the beneficiary meets this criterion, and the record contains no evidence relevant
to this criterion.
Fourth Criterion
To meet the fourth criterion, at 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2)(iv), you must submit a written statement
from an official of the governing body of the sport which details how the beneficiary or team is
internationally recognized. 
You do not claim that the beneficiary meets this criterion, and the record contains no evidence relevant
to this criterion.
Fifth Criterion
To meet the fifth criterion, at 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2)(v), you must submit a written statement
from a member of the sports media or a recognized expert in the sport which details how the
beneficiary or team is internationally recognized. 
The evidence you submitted is insufficient.

Sixth Criterion
To meet the sixth criterion, at 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2)(vi), you must submit evidence that the
individual or team is ranked if the sport has international rankings. 
Your included support letter states the following:
Jeremiah Elie meets and exceeds the requirement under 8 CFR 21 4.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2)(vi),
clearly demonstrated through his official international rankings achieved in prominent
bodybuilding competitions sanctioned by the International Federation of Bodybuilding and
Fitness (IFBB). These competitions are highly regarded globally, providing formal rankings
and placements of international competitors.
USCIS recognizes your submission of various documents showing the beneficiary placed at various
bodybuilding competitions.  However, you provided no evidence that the beneficiary holds an
international ranking in the respective sport.  Furthermore, you submitted no evidence that an
international ranking is available for the sport of bodybuilding.  Simply placing in various
competitions does not satisfy the plain language of this criterion. 
You have not submitted evidence the individual or team is ranked in the sport’s international
rankings.  Accordingly, you have not established that the beneficiary meets this criterion.
Seventh Criterion
To meet the seventh criterion, at 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(2)(vii), you must submit evidence that the

t appears that the beneficiary meets this criterion.
Conclusion
In view of the above, you have not established that the beneficiary qualifies for classification under 
the section 101(a)(15)(P)(i)(a) of the Act.  Therefore, your petition is denied.

 P-1A Individual Athletes and Athletic Teams
You, Innovative Global Talent Agency LLC, filed Form I-129, Petition for Nonimmigrant Worker,
seeking P-1A nonimmigrant classification for Jeremiah Elie.  You are seeking to employ or sponsor
the beneficiary as "World Class Bodybuilder/Fitness Competitor". 
The P-1A classification may be granted to internationally recognized athletes based on their
reputations and achievements as individuals.  It may also be granted to groups of two or more
individuals that function as a unit and are internationally recognized as teams.  Beneficiaries must be
coming to the United States to perform services requiring an internationally recognized athlete or team
at a specific athletic competition, as an athlete or team.
To process your petition and determine if the beneficiary is eligible, additional information is
required.  This request provides suggested evidence that you may submit to satisfy each requested
item.  You may: 
submit one, some, or all of these items;
submit none of the suggested items and instead submit other evidence to satisfy the request;
explain how the evidence in the record already establishes eligibility; and/or
request a decision based on the record. 
Prior Approvals
USCIS acknowledges that the beneficiary has previously been granted the benefit being sought, that
you are requesting to extend your petition and have requested USCIS grant deference to prior
approvals when evaluating the beneficiary's eligibility for the benefit being sought.  When
adjudicating a subsequent petition or application involving the same parties and the same underlying
facts, where appropriate, USCIS will generally defer to its prior determination of eligibility for the
particular nonimmigrant classification sought.
However, each petition filing is a separate proceeding with a separate record.  Despite any previously
approved petitions, the petitioner bears the burden to establish eligibility for each petition that it
submits, and an immigration benefit cannot be granted when the petitioner fails to meet its burden of
proof for the petition it files, including an extension petition. See INA § 291.  USCIS is not required to
approve petitions where eligibility has not been demonstrated, merely because of prior approvals
which may have been erroneous.  Matter of Church Scientology International, 19 I&N Dec. 593, 597
(Comm'r 1988).
USCIS will not defer to prior approvals where:
There was a material error with regard to the previous approval(s);  1.
There has been a material change in circumstances or eligibility requirements; or  2.
There is new material information that adversely impacts the petitioner’s, beneficiary’s, or
applicant’s eligibility.
3.
USCIS recognizes your petition includes statements and supporting evidence referencing the
beneficiary’s prior approvals for the requested classification.  USCIS has reviewed this instant petition
filed on behalf of the beneficiary.  There has been a material change in circumstances or eligibility
requirements.  On Form I-129 Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker, your requested filing
classification indicates there is a "Change of Employer".  Therefore, there has been a material change
in circumstances or eligibility requirements.

8 CFR 214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E) states the following relating to Agents filing as petitioners:
(E) Agents as petitioners. A United States agent may file a petition in cases involving workers
who are traditionally self-employed or workers who use agents to arrange short-term
employment on their behalf with numerous employers, and in cases where a foreign employer
authorizes the agent to act on its behalf. A United States agent may be: the actual employer of
the beneficiary; the representative of both the employer and the beneficiary; or, a person or
entity authorized by the employer to act for, or in place of, the employer as its agent. A
petition filed by an United States agent is subject to the following conditions:
(1) An agent performing the function of an employer must specify the wage offered and the
other terms and conditions of employment by contractual agreement with the beneficiary or
beneficiaries. The agent/employer must also provide an itinerary of definite employment
and information on any other services planned for the period of time requested.
(2) A person or company in business as an agent may file the P petition involving multiple
employers as the representative of both the employers and the beneficiary or beneficiaries if
the supporting documentation includes a complete itinerary of services or engagements. The
itinerary shall specify the dates of each service or engagement, the names and addresses of
the actual employers, the names and addresses of the establishment, venues, or locations
where the services will be performed. In questionable cases, a contract between the
employer(s) and the beneficiary or beneficiaries may be required. The burden is on the
agent to explain the terms and conditions of the employment and to provide any required
documentation.
(3) A foreign employer who, through a United States agent, files a petition for a P
nonimmigrant alien is responsible for complying with all of the employer sanctions
provisions of section 274A of the Act and 8 CFR part 274a.

employers/competitions who seek to hire the beneficiary.

beneficiary.

and the one or more employers who seek to hire the beneficiary.

Beneficiary Qualifications
You indicate the beneficiary qualifies for P-1 non-immigrant status.  As defined in statute and
regulation, a beneficiary may qualify for the P-1A classification as an internationally recognized
athlete, a professional athlete, an amateur athlete, or as a professional or amateur skater who performs
individually or as part of a group in a theatrical ice skating production.  
As you do not claim the beneficiary qualifies as an amateur athlete or a professional or amateur skater
who performs individually or as a part of a group in a theatrical ice skating production, these grounds
of eligibility will not be discussed further in this request.

Internationally Recognized Athlete or Team
A beneficiary may qualify as a P-1A internationally recognized athlete if the beneficiary performs as
an athlete, individually or as part of a group or team, at an internationally recognized level of
performance and seeks to enter the United States temporarily for the purpose of performing as such an
athlete with respect to a specific athletic competition. Specifically, the P-1A must be coming to
perform services which require an internationally recognized athlete or team. 
Internationally recognized means having a high level of achievement in a field evidenced by a degree
of skill and recognition substantially above that ordinarily encountered, to the extent that such
achievement is renowned, leading, or well-known in more than one country.
Solely Competing
In order to be eligible for the P-1A classification, the beneficiary must be coming to the United States 
solely for the purpose of performing in a specific athletic competition as an athlete or coach, as
applicable.  Alternatively, athletes coming to the United States to perform in theatrical ice skating
productions must be coming solely to perform in specific ice skating productions or tours.  Permissible
activities also include short vacations, promotional appearances for the petitioning employer relating to
the competition, event or performance, and stopovers which are incidental and/or related to the
activity.
The evidence you submitted is insufficient to establish that the beneficiary will be performing
(including permissible related/incidental activities) solely as an athlete with respect to a specific
athletic competition.

The O-1A classification applies to individuals with extraordinary ability in the sciences, education, business, or athletics.  The individual must
have sustained national or international acclaim.  The individual's achievements must be in the field of expertise and show that the
individual is one of a small percentage who has risen to the very top of the field.  The individual must be coming to the United States to
continue work in the individual's area of extraordinary ability.

credibility, both individually and within the context of the totality of evidence, to determine whether the fact to be proven is probably
true.  USCIS comprehensively reviews the entire body of evidence before rendering a final determination of eligibility.  Upon review of the
evidence you submitted in the initial filing, the record contains insufficient documentation to establish the beneficiary meets the regulatory
requirements for the O-1A classification.

evidence that you may submit to satisfy each requested item.  You may:

Prior Approvals
USCIS acknowledges that the beneficiary has previously been granted the benefit being sought and that you have requested USCIS grant
deference to prior approvals when evaluating the beneficiary's eligibility for the benefit being sought.  When adjudicating a subsequent
petition or application involving the same parties and the same underlying facts, where appropriate, USCIS will generally defer to its prior
determination of eligibility for the particular nonimmigrant classification sought.
However, each petition filing is a separate proceeding with a separate record.  Despite any previously approved petitions, the petitioner bears
the burden to establish eligibility for each petition that it submits, and an immigration benefit cannot be granted when the petitioner fails to
meet its burden of proof for the petition it files, including an extension petition. See INA § 291.  USCIS is not required to approve petitions
where eligibility has not been demonstrated, merely because of prior approvals which may have been erroneous.  Matter of Church
Scientology International, 19 I&N Dec. 593, 597 (Comm'r 1988).
USCIS will not defer to prior approvals where:
There was a material error with regard to the previous approval(s);  1.
There has been a material change in circumstances or eligibility requirements; or  2.
There is new material information that adversely impacts the petitioner’s, beneficiary’s, or applicant’s eligibility.3.
USCIS recognizes your petition includes statements and supporting evidence referencing the beneficiary’s prior approval for the requested
classification.  USCIS has reviewed this instant petition filed on behalf of the beneficiary.   On Form I-129 Petition for a Nonimmigrant
Worker, your requested filing classification indicates that the basis for requested classification is "Change of Employer”.  Therefore, there has
been a material change in circumstances or eligibility requirements.
Furthermore, USCIS reviewed the instant petition filed on behalf of the beneficiary and recognizes your request to grant deference to the prior
approvals the beneficiary has received.  However, you have not satisfied the regulatory requirements relating to general evidence required to
accompany all O petitions as described under 8 CFR 214.2(o)(2)(ii).  
Additionally, you have not established the requirements for agent petitioners as described under 8 CFR 214.2(o)(2)(iv)(E).
As such, if the same or similar evidence was submitted with the beneficiary's prior approval as has been submitted with this instant petition,
than there was a material error with regard to the previous approval. 
As stated above, despite any previously approved petitions, the petitioner bears the burden to establish eligibility for each petition that it
submits, and an immigration benefit cannot be granted when the petitioner fails to meet its burden of proof for the petition it files, including
an extension petition.
Moreover, you submitted no evidence of the beneficiary's prior approvals for the benefit being sought with this petition. 
Therefore, this petition must be supported by its own documentation and will be adjudicated based upon its own merits.  A more detailed
discussion about the deficiencies will be discussed below.  USCIS will not defer to its prior approval in adjudicating this petition.

General Requirements for All O-1A Nonimmigrant Petitions 
In general, petitions seeking O nonimmigrant classification must include: 
Copies of contracts;
A description of the competition(s), event(s), or performance(s); and
At least one consultation. 
To satisfy these requirements, you submitted: 
Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker;
Form I-129, O and P Classifications Supplement to Form I-129;
Petitioner support letter;
Attorney support letter;
RFE Support letter;
USCIS legal decision documents/memos;
Arrival/Departure documents;
Form(s) DS-2019, Certificate of Eligibility for Exchange Visitor (J-1) Status;
Form(s) I-20, Certificate of Eligibility for Nonimmigrant Student Status;
Prior approval notices;
Peer Group Advisory Letters;
Productions/Events supporting documentation;
Organizations/Establishments supporting documentation;
Media articles and supporting documentation;
Employment/Representation agreements;
Itinerary; and
Beneficiary’s identity documents.
Contracts
Petitions seeking O nonimmigrant classification must include a copy of a contract between the beneficiary and either the petitioner or the
employer.  If a written contract does not exist, you may submit a detailed summary of the terms of the oral agreement between the
beneficiary and either the petitioner or the employer.
The contract you submitted is insufficient.
The documentation you submitted is insufficient in establishing the regulatory requirements relating to contracts.  
Specifically, your support letter states that "The petitioner, Innovative Global Talent Agency, LLC, is serving in the capacity of U.S. Agent
for Foreign Employer."  However, the included documentation appears to indicate that you are the beneficiary's agent representing the
beneficiary and the one or more employers who seek to hire them.  As such, the submitted documentation does not sufficiently establish the
terms and conditions of the beneficiary's employment. 
For example, you submitted a "US AGENT REPRESENTATION AGREEMENT" which outlines the role of the petitioner agent under this
petition.  Your agreement indicates that the petitioner's role is to "Negotiate and coordinate arrangements with U.S. venues, promoters,
facilities, and business partners".  You seek to hire the beneficiary as a "World class Martial Artist".

(ii) Evidence required to accompany a petition. Petitions for O aliens shall be accompanied by the following:
(A) The evidence specified in the particular section for the classification;

any itinerary for the events or activities; and
(D) A written advisory opinion(s) from the appropriate consulting entity or entities.

Consultation
Petitions seeking O-1A nonimmigrant classification must include a written advisory opinion from a U.S. peer group, labor organization,
and/or management organization in the area of the beneficiary’s ability.  The U.S. peer group may include a person or persons with expertise
in the field. 
The documentation you submitted is insufficient. USCIS recognizes your statements indicating that a labor organization does not exist in the
beneficiary's field of expertise.  Furthermore, USCIS recognizes your submission of letters from the beneficiary's peer group.  While these
letters provide a general overview of the beneficiary's background and expertise, they do not specifically explain the nature of the duties to
be performed by the beneficiary and they do not sufficiently explain how and/or why the beneficiary's position specifically required the
services of an individual of extraordinary ability. 
You may submit a new consultation which meets the requirements specified below. 
A consultation is a written advisory opinion regarding the nature of the work and the beneficiary’s qualifications.  The advisory opinion must
state: 
The beneficiary’s ability and achievements in the field of endeavor;
The nature of the duties to be performed; and
Whether the position requires the services of an individual of extraordinary ability. 
The opinion should contain a statement of facts that supports the conclusion reached in the opinion.  If it is provided by a group or an
organization, it must be signed by an authorized official of the group or organization.  A consulting organization may also submit a letter of
no objection if it has no objection to the approval of the petition.

And

Agents representing both the beneficiary and one or more employers must submit: 
Evidence that the agent is authorized to act as an agent on behalf of the beneficiary and all of the entities with whom the beneficiary is
contracted to perform the services;
Contracts between the beneficiary and the entities with whom the beneficiary will perform services, explaining the terms and
conditions of employment; and

Specifies the dates of each service or engagement;

Provides the names and addresses of the establishments, venues, or locations where the services will be performed.

8 CFR 214.2(o)(2) states the following relating to the filing of O petitions:
General. Except as provided for in paragraph (o)(2)(iv)(A) of this section, a petitioner seeking to classify an alien as an O–1 or O–2
nonimmigrant shall file a petition on the form prescribed by USCIS. The petition may not be filed more than one year before the
actual need for the alien's services. An O–1 or O–2 petition shall be adjudicated at the appropriate Service Center, even in emergency
situations. Only one beneficiary may be included on an O–1 petition. O–2 aliens must be filed for on a separate petition from the
O–1 alien. An O–1 or O–2 petition may only be filed by a United States employer, a United States agent, or a foreign employer
through a United States agent. For purposes of paragraph o of this section, a foreign employer is any employer who is not amenable
to service of process in the United States. A foreign employer may not directly petition for an O nonimmigrant alien but instead must
use the services of a United States agent to file a petition for an O nonimmigrant alien. A United States agent petitioning on behalf of
a foreign employer must be authorized to file the petition, and to accept services of process in the United States in proceedings under
section 274A of the Act, on behalf of the foreign employer. An O alien may not petition for himself or herself.
As such, an O petition may be filed by a United States employer, a United States agent, or a foreign employer through a United States agent.

The included contract contradicts with your statements relating to this petition being filed by an agent representing a foreign employer for the
beneficiary.  Contrarily, your included contract appears to indicate that when competing the beneficiary is an independent contractor.
Furthermore, publicly available information relating to combat industry standards indicates that combat sports and/or boxing athletes are
traditionally self-employed and make contractual agreements directly with promoters for one or more scheduled bouts.
For example, a publicly available article from The Manual indicates the following relating to UFC fighter contracts:
Have you ever wondered what a UFC fighter’s contract looks like? When an MMA competitor signs a contract to fight three to four
annual fights, they give away representational rights. Instead of a union serving as an exclusive representative to collectively bargain
with the UFC for wages, hours, and working conditions, each professional is on his or her own, operating essentially as an
independent contractor. Under these agreements, fighters are obligated by the terms of contracts, no matter how onerous. And they
have no recourse should they be summarily released.
Denis, M. (2022). The Manual. “This is what you need to know about top-secret UFC fighter contracts With no union representation,
the UFC retains lucrative rights”. https://www.themanual.com/culture/ufc-fighter-contract/. Accessed October 28, 2025.
As such, publicly available evidence indicates that combat sports and/or boxing athletes are traditionally self-employed and make contractual
agreements directly with promoters for one or more scheduled bouts.
Based on conditions commonly contained in exclusive promotional agreements, as described in the articles referenced, it appears that control
over the beneficiary’s employment rests largely with the promotional company.  Correspondingly, the prevalence of such agreements directly
contradicts supporting evidence suggesting that you would retain a level of control indicative of a US Agent representing a foreign employer. 
As such, the submitted documentation appears to indicate that you are the beneficiary's agent representing the beneficiary and the one or
more employers who seek to hire them, not an agent representing a foreign employer as you claim. 
You have not established the regulatory requirements relating to U.S. agents filing on behalf of a foreign employer. 
You may still submit evidence to satisfy this requirement.

The O-1A classification applies to individuals with extraordinary ability in the sciences, education,
business, or athletics.  The individual must have sustained national or international acclaim.  The
individual's achievements must be in the field of expertise and show that the individual is one of the
small percentage who have risen to the very top of the field.  The individual must plan to continue to
work in the area of extraordinary ability.
To process your petition and determine if the beneficiary is eligible, additional information is
required.  This request provides suggested evidence that you may submit to satisfy each requested
item.  You may:
Submit one, some, or all of these items. 
Submit none of the suggested items and instead submit other evidence to satisfy the request. 
Explain how the evidence in the record already establishes eligibility.
Request a decision based on the record. 
Note, however, that you are responsible for providing evidence that best shows all requirements. 
Evidence must show eligibility for the requested benefit when you filed the petition.

Petitions seeking O nonimmigrant classification must include a copy of a contract between you and the
beneficiary. If a written contract does not exist, you may submit a detailed summary of the terms of
the oral agreement.

DECISION
Dear Sir/Madam, 
On June 26, 2025, you filed a Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker, to classify the
beneficiary as an athlete under section 101(a)(15)(P)(i)(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act
(Act).
Your Petition
You are a talent agency established in 2024.  Your currently employ two individuals.  You seek to 
represent the beneficiary as a "World Class Trick Rider" for a period of one year at a salary of $2,500
per performance.
The initial record did not establish the beneficiary qualifies for P-1 nonimmigrant classification. The
initial record did not demonstrate:
Written contracts between the petitioner and the alien beneficiary or, if there is no written
contract, a summary of the terms of the oral agreement under which the beneficiary will be
employed as required by Title 8 Code of Federal Regulations (8 CFR) section 214.2(p)(2)(ii);
You satisfied all of the conditions for an: 
Agent functioning as an employer as defined in 8 CFR 214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E)(1); and
Agent representing the beneficiary and multiple employers as defined in 8 CFR
214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E)(2).
The beneficiary is coming to the United States solely for the purpose of performing in a
specific athletic competition as an athlete as defined in section 214(c)(4)(A)(ii)(1);
The beneficiary is coming to the United States to participate in an athletic competition which
has a distinguished reputation and which requires participation of an athlete or athletic team that
has an international reputation as required in 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(A); and
The beneficiary has a tendered contract with a major United States sports league or team, or a
tendered contract in an individual sport commensurate with international recognition in that
sport, if such contracts are normally executed in the poker as required in 8 CFR
214.2(p)(4)(ii)(B)(1).
Therefore, on July 15, 2025, U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) issued a request for

Therefore, on July 15, 2025, U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) issued a request for
evidence (RFE) seeking additional documentation to overcome the deficiencies in the record.   
On September 16, 2025, USCIS received your response to the RFE which includes the following
evidence:
An RFE response letter;
A letter from the beneficiary authorizing you to act as an agent on behalf of her business entity;
A "Petition & Beneficiary Agreement";
"Specialty Act" contracts between the beneficiary and contracting parties;
An updated Itinerary of U.S. Engagements;
A "Foreign Employment Terms" agreement between the beneficiary and her business entity;
A photograph of the beneficary's rodeo cards;
 A testimonial letters;
Email correspondence;
Photographs of the beneficiary's belt buckles;
Photographs of the beneficiary's identification for rodeo events;
Photocopies of articles and programs; and
Photographs of award ribbons and trophy.
The record does not establish the beneficiary qualifies for the P-1A classification. All deficiencies in
the record will be further discussed below.
Prior Approvals
USCIS acknowledges that you are requesting to extend the beneficiary's current status as an P-1A
nonimmigrant.  When adjudicating a subsequent petition or application involving the same parties and
the same underlying facts, where appropriate, USCIS will generally defer to its prior determination of
eligibility for the particular nonimmigrant classification sought.
However, each petition filing is a separate proceeding with a separate record.  Despite any previously
approved petitions, the petitioner bears the burden to establish eligibility for each petition that it
submits, and an immigration benefit cannot be granted when the petitioner fails to meet its burden of
proof for the petition it files, including an extension petition. See INA § 291.  USCIS is not required to
approve petitions where eligibility has not been demonstrated, merely because of prior approvals
which may have been erroneous.  Matter of Church Scientology International, 19 I&N Dec. 593, 597
(Comm'r 1988).
USCIS will not defer to prior approvals where:
There was a material error with regard to the previous approval(s);  1.
There has been a material change in circumstances or eligibility requirements; or  2.
There is new material information that adversely impacts the petitioner’s, beneficiary’s, or
applicant’s eligibility.
3.
USCIS recognizes your petition includes statements and supporting evidence referencing the
beneficiary’s prior approvals for the requested classification.  USCIS has reviewed this instant petition
filed on behalf of the beneficiary.  There has been a material change in circumstances or eligibility
requirements.  On Form I-129 Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker, your requested filing
classification indicates there is a "Change of Employer".  Therefore, there has been a material change
in circumstances or eligibility requirements. 
Additionally, you have not established the requirements for agent petitioners as described under 8

USCIS encourages you to sign up for a USCIS online account. To learn more about creating an account and the benefits, go to https://www.uscis.gov/file-online.

Additionally, you have not established the requirements for agent petitioners as described under 8
CFR 214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E).  As such, there is new material information that adversely impacts the
petitioner’s, beneficiaries’, or applicant’s eligibility.  
Furthermore, if the same or similar evidence was submitted with the beneficiaries’ prior approvals,
there was a material error with regard to the previous approval(s).
As stated above, despite any previously approved petitions, the petitioner bears the burden to establish
eligibility for each petition that it submits, and an immigration benefit cannot be granted when the
petitioner fails to meet its burden of proof for the petition it files, including an extension petition.
Therefore, this petition must be supported by its own documentation and will be adjudicated based
upon its own merits.  A more detailed discussion about the deficiencies will be discussed below.
USCIS will not defer to its prior approval in adjudicating this petition.
General Requirements
Title 8 CFR section 214.2(p)(2)(ii) states:
Evidence required to accompany a petition for a P nonimmigrant. Petitions for P nonimmigrant
aliens shall be accompanied by the following:
A. The evidence specified in the specific section of this part for the classification;
B. Copies of any written contracts between the petitioner and the alien beneficiary or, if
there is no written contract, a summary of the terms of the oral agreement under which
the alien(s) will be employed;
C. An explanation of the nature of the events or activities, the beginning and ending
dates for the events or activities, and a copy of any itinerary for the events or activities;
and
D. A written consultation from a labor organization.
Contracts
The first issue is whether you have satisfied the contract requirement. Title 8 CFR 214.2(p)(2)(ii)(B)
requires copies of any written contracts between the petitioner and the alien beneficiary or, if there is
no written contract, a summary of the terms of the oral agreement under which the beneficiary will be
employed.
In addition,  8 CFR 103.2(b)(1) states:
(b) Evidence and processing
(1) Demonstrating eligibility. An applicant or petitioner must establish that he or she is
eligible for the requested benefit at the time of filing the benefit request and must
continue to be eligible through adjudication. Each benefit request must be properly
completed and filed with all initial evidence required by applicable regulations and other
USCIS instructions. Any evidence submitted in connection with a benefit request is
incorporated into and considered part of the request.
In the RFE, USCIS recognized your submission of a "Petitioner and Talent Agreement" between you
and the beneficiary. However, the initial record included conflicting information relating to the
relationship between you, the beneficiary, and the employers who seek to hire the beneficiary for

relationship between you, the beneficiary, and the employers who seek to hire the beneficiary for
services rendered.
For example, in your petition support letter you stated:
This letter is in connection with a P-1 A visa petition in which the Petitioner is acting as:
An employer with a bona fide job offer, where the Beneficiary will continue working directly in
her area of extraordinary ability. No third-party authorizations are required for this direct
employment.
The Petitioner agrees to do the following:
1. Represent the Beneficiary in activities and events related to trick riding performances
and competitions within the United States.
2. Accept service of process on behalf of the Beneficiary.
3. Arrange reasonable travel accommodations for the Beneficiary if the visa status is
terminated prematurely.
The Petitioner affirms that all information provided in this petition is true and accurate to the
best of its knowledge and belief. All involved parties have provided authorization for the
submission of this visa petition.
As such, in your petition support letter you claimed to be filing this petition as a U.S. agent performing

As explained above, in 8 CFR 103.2(b) a  petitioner must establish eligibility for the requested benefit
at the time of filing the benefit request.  Further, in is noted in Matter of Michelin Tire Corp., 17 I&N
Dec. 248 (Comm.1978),  the the petitioner must establish eligibility at the time of filing the visa
petition.  A visa petition may not be approved at a future date after the petitioner or beneficiary
becomes eligible under a new set of facts.
Moreover, the newly claim employment relationship between the beneficiary and her foreign
employer, Bell Da Costa Trick Riding, as well as the changes in wages earned by the beneficiary

petitioner may not make material corrections to his petition in an effort to make a deficient petition
conform to USCIS requirements. Matter of Izummi, 22 I&N Dec. 169 (Comm. 1998).
Considering the discussion above, the record does not establish the terms and conditions of the

employment during the requested validity period.  As such, your petition does not satisfy the
requirements of 8 CFR 214.2(p)(2)(ii).
Agent Petitioner
The second issue is that you have not satisfied the requirements for an agent as petitioner.
Title 8 CFR 214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E) states:
Agents as petitioners. A United States agent may file a petition in cases involving workers who

Agents as petitioners. A United States agent may file a petition in cases involving workers who
are traditionally self-employed or workers who use agents to arrange short-term employment
on their behalf with numerous employers, and in cases where a foreign employer authorizes the
agent to act on its behalf. A United States agent may be: the actual employer of the beneficiary;
the representative of both the employer and the beneficiary; or, a person or entity authorized by
the employer to act for, or in place of, the employer as its agent. A petition filed by a United
States agent is subject to the following conditions, in relevant part:
(1) An agent performing the function of an employer must specify the wage offered and
the other terms and conditions of employment by contractual agreement with the
beneficiary or beneficiaries. The agent/employer must also provide an itinerary of
definite employment and information on any other services planned for the period of
time requested.
(2) A person or company in business as an agent may file the P petition involving
multiple employers as the representative of both the employers and the beneficiary or
beneficiaries if the supporting documentation includes a complete itinerary of services or
engagements. The itinerary shall specify the dates of each service or engagement, the
names and addresses of the actual employers, the names and addresses of the
establishment, venues, or locations where the services will be performed. In questionable
cases, a contract between the employer(s) and the beneficiary or beneficiaries may be
required. The burden is on the agent to explain the terms and conditions of the
employment and to provide any required documentation.
(3) A foreign employer who, through a United States agent, files a petition for a P
nonimmigrant alien is responsible for complying with all of the employer sanctions
provisions of section 274A of the Act and 8 CFR part 274a. Agent Performing the
Functions of an Employer.
Agents Performing the Function of an Employer
