performing the function of an employer in this filing. The RFE notified you to satisfy the conditions
for filing as this type of agent you must submit:
A written contract, or if a written contract does not exist, the summary of the terms of the oral
agreement that: 
Specifies the wage offered and other terms of employment; and
Details any additional services provided.
An itinerary of definite employment and information on any other services planned for the
period of time requested. 
One of the U.S. agent scenarios that you initially put forward is that you are filing this petition as a
U.S. agent performing the function of the employer with "no third-party authorizations" required for

employer.  Further, the initial record did not contain evidence of any contractual agreement or
summary of terms for any future rodeo events establishing that, at the time of filing, your agency has
negotiated and arranged any events on the beneficiary’s behalf.

Agent for Foreign Employer
In your initial petition because you did not claim to be or provided evidence that you filed the petition
as a U.S. agent filing on behalf of a foreign employer.  Although this agent relationship was not
discussed specifically in the RFE, the evidence of record is insufficient to establish that, at the time
you filed the instant petition, you satisfied the conditions for filing the instant petition as a U.S. agent
filing on behalf of a foreign employer.
A foreign employer who, through a U.S. agent, files a petition for a P nonimmigrant alien is
responsible for complying with all of the employer sanctions provisions of section 274A of the Act
and 8 CFR part 274a, to include the actual commencement of employment of an employee for wages
or other remuneration.
In response to the RFE you provided a "Petitioner & Benefciary Agreement" that was entered into on
September 3, 2025, as well as an authorization letter from the beneficiary written on September 3,
2025 and a "Foreign Employment Terms" document signed on September 5, 2025.  USCIS notes that
all of these documents were entered into after the date you filed the instant petition and after the
issuance of the RFE. 
The newly claim employment relationship between the you, beneficiary and her foreign employer,
Bell Da Costa Trick Riding, as well as the changes in wages earned by the beneficiary appears to be a
material change in the the terms and conditions of the beneficiary's employment and your
representation of the foreign employer.  A petitioner may not make material corrections to his petition
in an effort to make a deficient petition conform to USCIS requirements. see Matter of Izummi.
Further, as explained above, in 8 CFR 103.2(b) a  petitioner must establish eligibility for the requested
benefit at the time of filing the benefit request.  Further,  the the petitioner must establish eligibility at
the time of filing the visa petition.  A visa petition may not be approved at a future date after the
petitioner or beneficiary becomes eligible under a new set of facts. see Matter of Michelin Tire Corp.
Finally, the "Specialty Act Contracts" appears to show that the contracting parties will pay the
beneficiary directly and not disburse payments to Bella Da Costa Trick Riding.  Payment directly to
the beneficiary from the contracting entities undermines your assertion that she will be employed by a
foreign employer.
Considering the discussion above, the evidence of record does not establish that you satisfied the
conditions for a U.S. agent filing on behalf of a foreign employer as defined in 8 CFR
214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E)(2).
Beneficiary Qualifications
You indicate the beneficiary qualifies for P-1 non-immigrant status. As defined in statute and
regulation, a beneficiary may qualify for the P-1A classification as an internationally recognized
athlete, a professional athlete, an amateur athlete, or as a professional or amateur skater who performs
individually or as part of a group in a theatrical ice skating production.
Section 214(c)(4)(A) of the Act states that for the purposes of section 101(a)(15)(P)(i)(a), an alien is
described in this subparagraph if the alien-
(i)(I) performs as an athlete, individually or as part of a group or team, at an internationally
recognized level of performance;

(II) is a professional athlete, as defined in section 204(i)(2);
(III) performs as an athlete, or as a coach, as part of a team or franchise that is located in the
United States and a member of a foreign league or association of 15 or more amateur sports
teams, if-- 
(aa) the foreign league or association is the highest level of amateur performance of
that sport in the relevant foreign country; 
(bb) participation in such league or association renders players ineligible, whether on

(IV) is a professional athlete or amateur athlete who performs individually or as part of a

and

(I) as such an athlete with respect to a specific athletic competition; or

As you do not claim the beneficiary qualifies as an amateur athlete or a professional or amateur skater
who performs individually or as a part of a group in a theatrical ice skating production these grounds
of eligibility will not be discussed further in this denial.
Requirements for Athletes and Teams
You indicate that the beneficiary or team has international recognition. In this situation, the P-1A
classification requires an athlete to have an internationally recognized reputation. Alternatively, an
athlete must be a member of a foreign team that is internationally recognized in the sport. The athlete
or team must be coming to the United States solely to participate in competitions that have
distinguished reputations. Petitions for:
1. Individual athletes, competing as individuals or on a U.S. team, must show the international
recognition is based on their individual accomplishments and that the services to be performed
require an internationally recognized athlete
2. A team must show that it has achieved international recognition and that the services to be
performed require an internationally recognized athletic team. Each member of the team then
receives P-1A classification based on the team’s recognition.
Solely to Compete

The third issue in this matter is whether the beneficiary is coming to the United States to compete as a
Trick Rider.
Title 8 Code of Federal Regulations (8 CFR), section 214.2(p)(1)(ii)(A) states:
A P-1 classification applies to an alien who is coming temporarily to the United
States:
To perform at a specific athletic competition as an athlete, individually or as part of a
group or team, at an internationally recognized level of performance, or
1.
To perform with, or as an integral and essential part of the performance of, an
entertainment group that has been recognized internationally as being outstanding in
the discipline for a sustained and substantial period of time, and who has had a
sustained and substantial relationship with the group (ordinarily for at least 1 year)
and provides functions integral to the performance of the group.
2.
The RFE notified you that the evidence you submitted with your petition was insufficient to establish
that the beneficiary will be performing (including permissible related/incidental activities) solely as an
athlete with respect to a specific athletic competition.
As explained in the RFE, you did not submit evidence that establishes the specific competition in
which the beneficiary will perform. Rather, you provided a list of "anticipated events". 
As it related to those "anticipated events", the "Roles & Description"  section of the itinerary indicates
that the beneficiary will perform for rodeos in roles such as "Featured Trick Rider", "Specialty Act", 
"Headlining Act", and "Closing Act".  The initial record did not establish that these roles are consistent
with an athlete competing in an athletic competition.  
In addition, the initially submitted itinerary shows that the beneficiary would participate in clinics and
expos in roles such as "Guest Clinician - Filmed Instructional appearances" at the PRCA Clinic and
Filming and "Demo Rider - Educational equestrian showcase" at the Idaho Horse Expo.  The
initial record did not establish that clinics and expos are athletic competitions.  For example, the
submitted articles about the Idaho Horse Expo provides a brief explanation of the event:
Each year the Idaho Horse Council produces the State’s largest equine EXPO which attracts
exhibitors and spectators from across the United States. The EXPO features highly regarded
trainers and clinicians from across the state and nation, the latest in products ranging from
jewelry to arena equipment, entertainment, industry-related seminars, youth activities, and
competitions from youth roping, to trail events and even jousting.
The initial record did not establish the Idaho Horse Expo is a Trick Riding competition or that the
beneficiary's participation in the Idaho Horse Expo will be a promotional appearance for her employer
relating to a competition. 
Finally, in her initially submitted statement, the beneficiary describes herself as a "Contract Act" and
explains that she performs acts at rodeos, but does not indicate that she competes in rodeo events.
In response to the RFE, you provided multiple "Specialty Act Contracts" between the Bella Da Costa
Trick Riding and contracting parties.  These "contracts" show that the beneficiary has entered into an
agreement with rodeo to perform a Trick Riding act for a fee.  The "Summary of Oral Terms &
Athlete Acceptance" documents further explain that the beneficiary will "perform specialty trick riding
routines" as a part of rodeos for which see will receive a performance fee. It does not appear the
beneficiary is coming to the United States to be a competitor in Trick Riding events.

Internationally Recognized Level of Competition
The fourth issue is whether the beneficiary is coming to the United States to participate in an athletic
competition which has a distinguished reputation and which requires participation of an athlete or
athletic team that has an international reputation as required in 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(A).
Describing the P-1 classification for athletes competing in an individual capacity, 8 CFR
214.2(p)(4)(i)(A) provides in pertinent part:
A P-1 classification may be granted to an alien who is an internationally recognized athlete
based on his or her own reputation and achievements as an individual. The alien must be
coming to the United States to perform services which require an internationally recognized
athlete.
Additionally, 8 CFR section 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(A) states:
General. A P-1 athlete must have an internationally recognized reputation as an international
athlete or he or she must be a member of a foreign team that is internationally recognized. The
athlete or team must be coming to the United States to participate in an athletic competition
which has a distinguished reputation and which requires participation of an athlete or athletic
team that has an international reputation.
The initial record did not contain corroborative documentation that that would establish that the
beneficiary is coming to the United States to participate in an athletic competition which has a
distinguished reputation, and which requires participation of an athlete or athletic team that has an
international reputation.
Lastly, 8 CFR section 214.2(p)(4)(ii)(A) states: 
General.  A P-1 athlete must have an internationally recognized reputation as an international
athlete or he or she must be a member of a foreign team that is internationally recognized.  The
athlete or team must be coming to the United States to participate in an athletic competition
which has a distinguished reputation and which requires participation of an athlete or athletic
team that has an international reputation. 
With your petition, you submitted various articles about the rodeos in which the beneficiary will
perform.  However, while these documents provide a general overview of the rodeos, they do not
sufficiently establish how and/or why the beneficiary's Trick Riding performance is an athletic
competition or a league that has a distinguished reputation and which requires participation of an
athlete or athletic team that has an international reputation.

showcase" at the Idaho Horse Expo. Therefore, the initial record does not establish that the
beneficiary's roles as explained in the itinerary are consistent with an athlete competing in an athletic
competition or league requires participation of an athlete or athletic team that has an international
reputation. 
In response to the RFE, you provided multiple "Specialty Act Contracts" between the Bella Da Costa
Trick Riding and contracting parties.  These "contracts" show that the beneficiary has entered into an
agreement with rodeo to perform a Trick Riding act for a fee.  The "Summary of Oral Terms &
Athlete Acceptance" documents further explain that the beneficiary will "perform specialty trick riding
routines" as a part of rodeos for which see will receive a performance fee. As explained above, it does
not appear the beneficiary is coming to the United States to be a competitor in Trick Riding events.
Further, the"Specialty Act Contracts"between the beneficiary and multiple contracting parties that
were signed by all parties on September 4, 2025, as evidence of the beneficiary's definite
employment.  The newly submitted documentation includes entirely different events and different
dates.
As explained above, in 8 CFR 103.2(b) a  petitioner must establish eligibility for the requested benefit
at the time of filing the benefit request.  Further,  the the petitioner must establish eligibility at the time
of filing the visa petition.  A visa petition may not be approved at a future date after the petitioner or
beneficiary becomes eligible under a new set of facts. see Matter of Michelin Tire Corp.
Considering the discussion above, the "Specialty Act Contracts" do not establish the beneficiary is
coming to the United States to participate in an athletic competition or league that has a distinguished
reputation and which requires participation of an athlete or athletic team that has an international
reputation. Accordingly, you have not established that the beneficiary satisfies this requirement.
Tendered Contract
The fifth issue is whether you have included a tendered contract with a major United States sports
league or team, or a tendered contract in an individual sport commensurate with international
recognition in that sport, if such contracts are normally executed in the sport.
Title 8 CFR 214.2(p)(4)(ii) (B)(1), which sets forth the documentary requirements for P-1 athletes,
states in part that the petition shall include:
A tendered contract with a major United States sports league or team, or a tendered contract in
an individual sport commensurate with international recognition in that sport, if such contracts
are normally executed in the sport.
Additionally, the USCIS Policy Manual, Volume 2, Part N, Chapter 4, states that:
A petition for an athletic team or individual athlete must include a tendered contract with a
“major United States sports league or team” or tendered contract in an individual sport
commensurate with international recognition in that sport, if such contracts are normally
executed in the sport. USCIS interprets “major United States sports league” as a league that has
a distinguished reputation that is commensurate with an internationally recognized level of
performance, and “major United States sports team” as a team that participates in such a league,
consistent with the statutory standard for internationally recognized athletes.

Therefore, under this interpretation, the league (or the team within the league) may be one where the
level of competition in the league is such that the league (or a team within the league) would not be
able to remain competitive or maintain its current distinguished reputation in the sport without the
services of at least some internationally recognized caliber athletes. 
You submitted no contracts with the organizing bodies or official invites to any of the events listed in
the itinerary with your petition.  Further, the initial record was absent supporting documentation about
the events listed on the itinerary that would establish the events' status as internationally recognized
events and are considered major United States sports leagues.
Further, as explained above, the initially submitted itinerary indicates that the beneficiary would
perform for rodeos in roles such as "Featured Trick Rider", "Specialty Act",  "Headlining Act", and
"Closing Act".   In addition, the initially submitted itinerary shows that the beneficiary
would participate in clinics and expos in roles such as "Guest Clinician - Filmed Instructional
appearances" at the PRCA Clinic and Filming and "Demo Rider - Educational equestrian showcase" at
the Idaho Horse Expo. 
In response to the RFE you provided provided multiple "Specialty Act Contracts" between the Bella

entered into an agreement with rodeo to perform a Trick Riding act for a fee.  The "Summary of Oral
Terms & Athlete Acceptance" documents further explain that the beneficiary will "perform specialty
trick riding routines" as a part of rodeos for which see will receive a performance fee. However, as
explained above, it does not appear the beneficiary is coming to the United States to be a competitor in
Trick Riding events.
Further, the"Specialty Act Contracts"between the beneficiary and multiple contracting parties that
were signed by all parties on September 4, 2025, as evidence of the beneficiary's definite
employment.  The newly submitted documentation includes entirely different events and different
dates.
As explained above, in 8 CFR 103.2(b) a  petitioner must establish eligibility for the requested benefit
at the time of filing the benefit request.  Further,  the the petitioner must establish eligibility at the time
of filing the visa petition.  A visa petition may not be approved at a future date after the petitioner or
beneficiary becomes eligible under a new set of facts. see Matter of Michelin Tire Corp.
Therefore, the evidence of record does not demonstrate that the beneficiary has a tendered contract
with a major U.S. sports league or team, or a tendered contract in an individual sport commensurate
with international recognition in that sport.
Conclusion
In view of the above, the record does not establish:
The record includes written contracts between the petitioner and the alien beneficiary or, if
there is no written contract, a summary of the terms of the oral agreement under which the
beneficiary will be employed as required by Title 8 Code of Federal Regulations (8 CFR)
section 214.2(p)(2)(ii);
You have satisfied all of the conditions for an: 
Agent functioning as an employer as defined in 8 CFR 214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E)(1); 
Agent representing the beneficiary and multiple employers as defined in 8 CFR
214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E)(2);
Agent filing on behalf of a foreign employer as defined in 8 CFR 214.2(p)(2)(iv)(E)(3)
The beneficiary is coming to the United States solely for the purpose of performing in a
specific athletic competition as an athlete as defined in section 214(c)(4)(A)(ii)(1);

I-129 O-1A Extraordinary Ability in Science, Education, Business, or Athletics
You, Innovative Global Talent Agency LLC, filed Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker,
seeking O-1A nonimmigrant classification for Montana Gaye O'Donoghue Kent as a "World Class
Barrel Racer".
The O-1A classification applies to individuals with extraordinary ability in the sciences, education,
business, or athletics.  The individual must have sustained national or international acclaim.  The
individual's achievements must be in the field of expertise and show that the individual is one of a
small percentage who has risen to the very top of the field.  The individual must be coming to the
United States to continue work in the individual's area of extraordinary ability.
Pursuant to the preponderance of evidence standard, USCIS will examine each piece of evidence for
relevance, probative value, and credibility, both individually and within the context of the totality of
evidence, to determine whether the fact to be proven is probably true.  USCIS comprehensively
reviews the entire body of evidence before rendering a final determination of eligibility.  Upon review
of the evidence you submitted in the initial filing, the record contains insufficient documentation to
establish the beneficiary meets the regulatory requirements for the O-1A classification. 
To process your petition and determine if the beneficiary is eligible, additional information is
required.  This request provides suggested evidence that you may submit to satisfy each requested
item.  You may:
Submit one, some, or all of these items;
Submit none of the suggested items and instead submit other evidence to satisfy the request;
Explain how the evidence in the record already establishes eligibility; and/or
Request a decision based on the record. 
Note, however, that you are responsible for providing evidence that best shows that you and the parties
to this petition meet all requirements.  Evidence must show that all parties were eligible for the
requested benefit when you filed Form I-129.
Note: When submitting additional evidence, please indicate to which individual criterion it applies.  If
you choose to submit comparable evidence in lieu of one or more of the criteria below, please indicate
why the criteria you wish to replace do not apply to the occupation.  
Additionally, when submitting articles, internet abstracts, and other documentation (excluding
testimonial letters) that includes the beneficiary’s name, please highlight the beneficiary’s name.  
Please submit evidence that is the most current and is presented in an orderly fashion. Illegible
photocopies will not be accepted as valid evidence.
Request for Translations
All foreign language documents must have a complete English translation to establish eligibility.  This
includes any documents you submit in response to this Request for Evidence.  In order for USCIS to
consider this evidence, you must submit English language translations for each document.  The
translator must certify that:
The translations are accurate and complete; and
The translator is competent to translate from the foreign language into English.

qualifications.  The advisory opinion must state: 
The beneficiary’s ability and achievements in the field of endeavor;
The nature of the duties to be performed; and
Whether the position requires the services of an individual of extraordinary ability.

it is provided by a group or an organization, it must be signed by an authorized official of the group or
organization.  A consulting organization may also submit a letter of no objection if it has no objection
to the approval of the petition.

submit evidence that shows you are authorized to: 
File the petition; and
Accept service of process in the United States on behalf of the foreign
employer.                                                                                                                                               
The evidence you submitted is insufficient.

You have provided conflicting statements relating to the nature of the relationship between the
beneficiary, petitioner and the beneficiary's ultimate employer. 
USCIS recognizes that your included support letter states the following:
The Petitioner, Innovative Global Talent Agency ("IGTA"), is a U.S.-based entity authorized
under 8 C.F.R. § 21 4.2(o)(2)(iv)(E) to act as U.S. Agent for a Foreign Employer who is
Self-Employed In this capacity, IGTA coordinates the Beneficiary’s activities in the United
States, ensures compliance with labor and immigration regulations, and accepts service of
process on behalf of the Beneficiary.
However, as stated above, it appears that control over the beneficiary’s employment rests largely with
the rodeo organization, individual racer, sponsor, etc.  Correspondingly, the prevalence of such
agreements directly contradicts supporting evidence suggesting that you would retain a level of
control indicative of a US Agent representing a foreign employer.  As such, the submitted
documentation appears to indicate that you are the beneficiary's agent representing the beneficiary and
the one or more employers who seek to hire them. 
Moreover, you did not submit any evidence from a foreign employer establishing that you are
authorized to file this petition and accept service of process in the United States on behalf of the
foreign employer.
Therefore, the submitted evidence does not establish the regulatory requirements relating to agents
petitioning on behalf of a foreign employer. 
You may still submit evidence to satisfy this requirement. 
Evidence of Sustained National or International Acclaim
You must show that the beneficiary has sustained national or international acclaim and recognition for
achievements in the field of expertise.  To demonstrate this, you may submit documentation to show
the beneficiary received a major, internationally recognized award, such as the Nobel Prize. 
Alternatively, you may show that the beneficiary satisfies at least three of the eight criteria discussed
below.  Ultimately, the totality of the evidence must establish that the beneficiary has sustained
national or international acclaim and that the beneficiary’s level of expertise indicates that the
beneficiary is one of that small percentage who has risen to the very top of the field.
Evidence of a Major, Internationally Recognized Award
You did not submit any evidence for this option.  You may still submit evidence to satisfy it.
You may still submit evidence to satisfy this option.  Evidence that can help USCIS determine that the
award is major and internationally recognized may show:
The award is internationally recognized as one of the top awards for the field;
The criteria used to grant the award;
The significance of the award in the field;
The reputation of the organization or the panel granting the award;
Previous winners of the award who held international acclaim at the time of receiving the
award; or
How the award attracts competition from internationally recognized individuals in the field.

Awards 
You may submit evidence showing the beneficiary received nationally or internationally recognized
prizes or awards for excellence in the field.  These are awards that do not meet the level of a major,
internationally recognized award that would satisfy that alternate requirement.
The evidence you submitted is insufficient.
To meet the plain language of this criterion, you must submit documentation of the beneficiary’s
receipt of nationally or internationally recognized prizes or awards for excellence in the field of
endeavor.  See 8 CFR 214.2(o)(3)(iii)(B)(1).
Accordingly, you must submit evidence establishing 1. That the accolade/distinction is by definition
an award or prize, 2. That the beneficiary was the recipient of the award or prize, 3. That the award or
prize is nationally or internationally recognized, and 4. That the award or prize is in the beneficiary’s
specific field of endeavor.
Your support letter states the following regarding the beneficiary’s eligibility under this criterion:
Evidence Provided
Montana Gaye O’Donoghue-Kent’s career features consistent recognition at the most elite
levels of professional barrel racing, a field where success is measured by performance in
high-stakes, restricted-entry competitions with substantial prize purses. These events, due to
their exclusivity and payout scale, are recognized as benchmarks of excellence in the sport.

The evidence you submitted is insufficient.
The plain language of this criterion requires evidence (1) of the beneficiary’s membership in an
association, (2) that the association be in the alien’s academic field, (3) that the association requires
outstanding achievements of their members, and (4) those achievements have been judged by
recognized national or international experts in their disciplines or fields.
Your support letter states the following regarding the beneficiary’s eligibility under this criterion:
Comparable Evidence Provision
Under 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(o)(3)(v), where public-facing membership organizations are not

Evidence Provided
Due to the specialized nature of professional barrel racing and the rodeo circuit, formal public
membership in selective associations is rare; instead, elite status is recognized through:

Entry into the Pink Buckle, Ruby Buckle, National Finals Rodeo, and Calgary Stampede

Engagements from leading horse owners and breeders — including Rylan Heller and

4. Integration into the PRCA/WPRA Professional Circuit
Active participation in the PRCA/WPRA circuit at events where entry is dependent on
verified qualifications, competitive earnings, and professional status within the sport
(Exhibits 7, 9, 20, 23).

Judging the Work of Others 
You may submit evidence showing the beneficiary has participated as a judge or on a panel that
evaluated the work of others.  The work must have been in the beneficiary's field of specialization or in
an associated field.
The evidence you submitted is insufficient. 
To meet the plain language of this criterion, you must submit evidence of the beneficiary’s
participation on a panel, or individually, as a judge of the work of others in the same or in an allied
field of specialization to that for which classification is sought.  See 8 CFR 214.2(o)(3)(iii)(B)(4).
As such, you must establish 1. That the beneficiary participated on a panel or individually as a judge,
and 2. That the beneficiary evaluated the work of others in an allied field of specialization to that for
which classification is sought.

for elite events.

USCIS acknowledges the author's statements indicating that "One of the greatest testaments to
Montana’s abilities is "Cashin in the Fame" aka "Bobby", a horse she trained in Australia and brought
to the United States. Bobby has gone on to compete successfully at top-level events with me and
currently part of my competition string. Montana laid the foundation for this horse’s success, and it’s
clear that her training methods are effective at the highest levels of rodeo competition”.  However,
while these statements provide a general overview of the beneficiary’s skills, abilities and
achievements, and prior work with a specific horse and individual in general terms, the author did not
specifically list how and/or why the beneficiary's specific individual contributions resulted in original
scientific, scholarly, or business-related contributions of major significance in the field.  For example,
the author did not submit a sufficiently detailed explanation and/or objective, supporting documentary
evidence establishing specifically how and/or why the beneficiary's work/individual contributions are
being implemented by others in the field, how and/or why the beneficiary’s work/individual
contributions have provoked widespread public commentary, and how and/or why beneficiary has
patents and/or licensed technology being used by others as a result of their specific contributions or
other similar supporting evidence establishing how and why the beneficiary's work is an original
contribution of major significance in the field of endeavor or how the beneficiary’s work is being
utilized or implemented by others in the field of endeavor.  To satisfy this criterion, the record must
not only establish the beneficiary’s contributions as original or novel, but the record must also show
the beneficiary’s contributions to the industry have had a major impact to the field. 
Although the authors of the letters claim the beneficiary has made contributions in the field of
endeavor, the documentation to show that the beneficiary's work is being implemented by others in the
field, does not demonstrate that the beneficiary’s work has provoked widespread public commentary,
and/or that the beneficiary has patents and/or licensed technology being used by others.  Simply
having others cite the beneficiary’s work is insufficient to satisfy this criterion.  Please note, that while
having others in the field cite the beneficiary’s work is noteworthy, it does not establish that work is of
major significance in the field.
Furthermore, the some authors did not provide a title or list any information regarding their authority,
expertise, and knowledge of the beneficiary’s achievements.  While this provides a general overview
of the beneficiary's skills and abilities and their experience working together, the letters do not contain
sufficient detail regarding the author’s credentials, the significance of their achievements, or the
distinguished reputation of the organizations they represent that would establish they are a recognized
expert in the field.
Additionally, USCIS acknowledges your submission of statements and supporting documentation
referring to media publications having covered the beneficiary and their work.  However, while these
articles discuss the beneficiary's work and their companies in general terms, the article's do not

implementation, or commentary, having prior work cited in a media article indirectly is insufficient in

the beneficiary’s contributions as original or novel, the record must also show the beneficiary’s

Moreover, as stated above, to meet the plain language of this criterion you must establish that the
beneficiary was employed by organizations or establishments.  USCIS recognizes your statements and
supporting evidence relating to the beneficiary’s role with various individuals and/or "Event teams". 
However, you have not established that these are organizations or establishments per the plain
language definition.  Simply working with an individual or group, without providing sufficient
supporting evidence indicating that the beneficiary was an employee with an organization or
establishment with a distinguished reputation is insufficient in meeting the plain language requirements
of this criterion.
In addition, your support letter repeatedly references submitted "contracts".  For example, you state
that the beneficiary has "ongoing and prior engagements" with organizations such as "major world
rodeo organizations".  However, you submitted no contracts relating to the beneficiary's prior
employment with your filing. 
You may still submit evidence to satisfy this criterion. 
Evidence may include, but is not limited to, documentation that establishes the beneficiary's
employment in a critical capacity with an organization or establishment that has a distinguished
reputation.

Remuneration 
You may submit evidence showing the beneficiary has commanded, now commands, or will command
a high salary or other substantial compensation.
You did not submit any evidence for this option.  You may still submit evidence to satisfy it.
The evidence to establish whether the beneficiary's compensation is high relative to others working in
the field may take many forms.  Examples may include but are not limited to:
Copies of contracts or similar reliable evidence;
Documents showing the beneficiary received a high salary, or other significant forms of
compensation, for services in comparison to others in the field, which may include equity in
lieu of cash;
A statistical comparison of the salaries in the beneficiary's field from a government or private
institution or a similar organization.  This should show that the beneficiary commanded a high
salary, or other significantly high remuneration, for services compared to others in the field;
Geographical or position-appropriate compensation surveys and organizational justifications to
pay above the compensation data;
The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS): http://www.bls.gov/bls/blswage.htm; 
The Department of Labor's Career One Stop website: 
http://www.careeronestop.org/SalariesBenefits/Sal_default.aspx;
The Department of Labor's Office of Foreign Labor Certification Online Wage Library: 
http://www.flcdatacenter.com;
Testimony from industry experts; and
Other corroborative evidence showing that the wage rate is high relative to others working in
the field.
Note:  U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) prevailing wage rate information alone does not
generally establish a salary or other remuneration is "significantly" higher than others in the
field.  If you submit DOL prevailing wage rate information, you should submit additional
evidence showing that the wage rate is high relative to others working in the field (such as the
examples above).

The main purpose of barrel racing is to run a set pattern as fast as possible. The times are
measured either by an electric eye, a device using a laser system to record times, or by a judge
who drops a flag to let the timer know when to start and stop the clock. Judges and timers are
more commonly seen in local and non-professional events. The timer begins when horse and
rider cross the starting line, and ends when the barrel pattern has been successfully executed
and horse and rider cross the finish line. Success depends on several factors, most commonly
the horse's physical and mental condition, the rider's horsemanship abilities, and the type of
ground or footing (the quality, depth, content, etc. of the sand or dirt in the arena).

I-129 O-1A Extraordinary Ability in Science, Education, Business, or Athletics
You, Innovative Global Talent Agency LLC, filed Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker,
seeking O-1A nonimmigrant classification for Dylan Shaun Cooke as a "Motorsport Crew Chief and
Setup Specialist".
The O-1A classification applies to individuals with extraordinary ability in the sciences, education,
business, or athletics.  The individual must have sustained national or international acclaim.  The
individual's achievements must be in the field of expertise and show that the individual is one of a
small percentage who has risen to the very top of the field.  The individual must be coming to the
United States to continue work in the individual's area of extraordinary ability.
Pursuant to the preponderance of evidence standard, USCIS will examine each piece of evidence for
relevance, probative value, and credibility, both individually and within the context of the totality of
evidence, to determine whether the fact to be proven is probably true.  USCIS comprehensively
reviews the entire body of evidence before rendering a final determination of eligibility.  Upon review
of the evidence you submitted in the initial filing, the record contains insufficient documentation to
establish the beneficiary meets the regulatory requirements for the O-1A classification. 
To process your petition and determine if the beneficiary is eligible, additional information is
required.  This request provides suggested evidence that you may submit to satisfy each requested
item.  You may:

In addition to demonstrating the beneficiary’s extraordinary ability and recognition in the field, a
petitioner must demonstrate that an O-1A or O-1B (Arts) beneficiary is coming to the United States to
continue work in the “area of extraordinary ability.”  There is no statutory or regulatory definition of
the term “field” or the phrase “area of extraordinary ability.” For purposes of evaluating an O-1A or
O-1B (Arts) beneficiary’s extraordinary ability in the field, USCIS interprets the term “field” to allow
consideration of acclaim and recognition for achievements in multiple related occupations (that is,
those involving shared skillsets, knowledge, or expertise). Similarly, in the O-1A or O-1B (Arts)
context, USCIS interprets the phrase “area of extraordinary ability” broadly to include not only the
specific occupation(s) in which the beneficiary has garnered acclaim, but also other occupations that

Field of Endeavor
The duties of a race car driver and a "Motorsport Crew Chief and Setup Specialist" involve two
completely different skillsets and have completely different duties.  The majority of the evidence
submitted relates to the beneficiary's career as a driver.  The evidence in the record is insufficient to
establish that the occupation of driver sufficiently shares skillsets, knowledge, or expertise with that of
"Motorsport Crew Chief and Setup Specialist".  Therefore, the record does not show the occupation of
"Motorsport Crew Chief and Setup Specialist" to be within the beneficiary’s field or area of
extraordinary ability.
If you would like USCIS to consider evidence of the beneficiary’s ability and experience as a driver in
relation to a "Motorsport Crew Chief and Setup Specialist", you may submit evidence that the
occupations share skillsets, knowledge, or expertise.
Relevant evidence may include but is not limited to evidence that:
The occupations are in the same industry or are otherwise related based on shared duties or
expertise;
One occupation is a supervisory, management, or other leadership position that oversees the
beneficiary’s previous positions or otherwise requires shared knowledge, skills, or expertise;
It is common for persons in one occupation to transition to the other occupation(s) based upon
their experience and knowledge.

A United States agent may file a petition in cases involving workers who are traditionally
self-employed or workers who use agents to arrange short-term employment on their behalf
with numerous employers, and in cases where a foreign employer authorizes the agent to act in
its behalf.  A United States agent may be:  The actual employer of the beneficiary, the
representative of both the employer and the beneficiary; or, a person or entity authorized by the
employer to act for, or in place of, the employer as its agent.  A petition filed by an agent is
subject to the following conditions: 
An agent performing the function of an employer must provide the contractual
agreement between the agent and the beneficiary which specifies the wage
offered and the other terms and conditions of employment of the beneficiary.
1.

engagement, the names and addresses of the actual employers, and the names
and addresses of the establishments, venues, or locations where the services will
be performed.  A contract between the employers and the beneficiary is
required.  The burden is on the agent to explain the terms and conditions of the
employment and to provide any required documentation.

Evidence of Sustained National or International Acclaim
You must show that the beneficiary has sustained national or international acclaim and recognition for
achievements in the field of expertise.  To demonstrate this, you may submit documentation to show
the beneficiary received a major, internationally recognized award, such as the Nobel Prize. 
Alternatively, you may show that the beneficiary satisfies at least three of the eight criteria discussed
below.  Ultimately, the totality of the evidence must establish that the beneficiary has sustained
national or international acclaim and that the beneficiary’s level of expertise indicates that the
beneficiary is one of that small percentage who has risen to the very top of the field.

The criteria used to grant the award;

The evidence you submitted is insufficient.

receipt of nationally or internationally recognized prizes or awards for excellence in the field of
endeavor.  See 8 CFR 214.2(o)(3)(iii)(B)(1).
Accordingly, you must submit evidence establishing 1. That the accolade/distinction is by definition
an award or prize, 2. That the beneficiary was the recipient of the award or prize, 3. That the award or
prize is nationally or internationally recognized, and 4. That the award or prize is in the beneficiary’s
specific field of endeavor.

To meet the plain language of this requirement, you must submit sufficient evidence establishing that
the beneficiary has been employed in a critical or essential capacity for organizations and
establishments that have a distinguished reputation.  See 8 CFR 214.2(o)(3)(iii)(B)(7).
Therefore, you must submit evidence that 1. The beneficiary was employed by the organizations or
establishments 2. That the beneficiary’s role was critical or essential, and 3. That those organizations
or establishments have a distinguished reputation.
Your support letter states the following regarding the beneficiary’s eligibility under this criterion:
Employment in a Critical Role for Distinguished Organizations - Mr. Cooke has been engaged
by Keith Kunz Motorsports (KKM) of Columbus, Indiana—one of America’s most respected
racing teams—where he serves as Crew Chief and Setup Specialist. His engineering insight and
track-side decision-making are critical to KKM’s competitive success in USAC and POWRi
national events (Exhibit 7).
It appears you are seeking to submit evidence relating to the beneficiary’s future employment with the
petitioner as supporting evidence under this criterion.  Please note, 8 CFR 214.2(o)(3)(iii)(B)(7) states
the following relating to evidentiary requirements for establishing the beneficiary’s eligibility under
this criterion:
Evidence that the alien has been employed in a critical or essential capacity for organizations
and establishments that have a distinguished reputation.
USCIS recognizes your submission and statements indicating that you wish to have the beneficiary’s
future employment with the petitioner to be considered as evidence under this criterion.  However, as
stated above, to establish eligibility under this criterion, you must submit evidence showing the
beneficiary “has been” employed in a critical or essential capacity for organizations and
establishments that have distinguished reputations.  Evidence relating to future employment does not
meet the plain language of this criterion. 
You may still submit evidence to satisfy this criterion. 
Evidence may include, but is not limited to, documentation that establishes the beneficiary's
employment in a critical capacity with an organization or establishment that has a distinguished
reputation.
Remuneration 
You may submit evidence showing the beneficiary has commanded, now commands, or will command
a high salary or other substantial compensation.
You did not submit any evidence for this option.  You may still submit evidence to satisfy it.
The evidence to establish whether the beneficiary's compensation is high relative to others working in
the field may take many forms.  Examples may include but are not limited to:
Copies of contracts or similar reliable evidence;
Documents showing the beneficiary received a high salary, or other significant forms of
compensation, for services in comparison to others in the field, which may include equity in
lieu of cash;
A statistical comparison of the salaries in the beneficiary's field from a government or private
institution or a similar organization.  This should show that the beneficiary commanded a high
salary, or other significantly high remuneration, for services compared to others in the field;

I-129 O-1A Extraordinary Ability in Science, Education, Business, or Athletics
You,Innovative Global Talent Agency LLC, filed Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker,
seeking O-1A nonimmigrant classification for Jiajun He as a "World Class Tennis Coach".
The O-1A classification applies to individuals with extraordinary ability in the sciences, education,
business, or athletics.  The individual must have sustained national or international acclaim.  The
individual's achievements must be in the field of expertise and show that the individual is one of a
small percentage who has risen to the very top of the field.  The individual must be coming to the
United States to continue work in the individual's area of extraordinary ability.
Pursuant to the preponderance of evidence standard, USCIS will examine each piece of evidence for
relevance, probative value, and credibility, both individually and within the context of the totality of
evidence, to determine whether the fact to be proven is probably true.  USCIS comprehensively
reviews the entire body of evidence before rendering a final determination of eligibility.  Upon review
of the evidence you submitted in the initial filing, the record contains insufficient documentation to
establish the beneficiary meets the regulatory requirements for the O-1A classification. 
To process your petition and determine if the beneficiary is eligible, additional information is required. 
Request for Biometrics 
USCIS must determine if the beneficiary qualifies for the benefit requested.  This determination
includes verifying the identity of the beneficiary and confirming information related to criminality,
national security, and similar issues that may impact the beneficiary’s eligibility for the benefit
requested. 
Accordingly, your Form I-129 cannot be processed until the beneficiary has appeared at an
Application Support Center (ASC) for the collection of a digital photograph, signature and
fingerprint(s). Our records indicate that the beneficiary has not yet appeared at an ASC for this
purpose. The beneficiary should follow the instructions on the ASC Appointment Notice that will be
mailed to them separately. Additional information regarding the location of the ASC can be found on
the USCIS web site at www.USCIS.gov.
Once the beneficiary has appeared at an ASC for biometrics capture, please return this notice to the
address indicated on this RFE.

individual's achievements must be in the field of expertise and show that the individual is one of a
small percentage who has risen to the very top of the field.  The individual must be coming to the
United States to continue work in the individual's area of extraordinary ability.
Pursuant to the preponderance of evidence standard, USCIS will examine each piece of evidence for
relevance, probative value, and credibility, both individually and within the context of the totality of
evidence, to determine whether the fact to be proven is probably true.  USCIS comprehensively
reviews the entire body of evidence before rendering a final determination of eligibility.  Upon review
of the evidence you submitted in the initial filing, the record contains insufficient documentation to
establish the beneficiary meets the regulatory requirements for the O-1A classification. 
To process your petition and determine if the beneficiary is eligible, additional information is required. 
Request for Biometrics 
USCIS must determine if the beneficiary qualifies for the benefit requested.  This determination
includes verifying the identity of the beneficiary and confirming information related to criminality,
national security, and similar issues that may impact the beneficiary’s eligibility for the benefit
requested. 
Accordingly, your Form I-129 cannot be processed until the beneficiary has appeared at an
Application Support Center (ASC) for the collection of a digital photograph, signature and
fingerprint(s). Our records indicate that the beneficiary has not yet appeared at an ASC for this
purpose. The beneficiary should follow the instructions on the ASC Appointment Notice that will be
mailed to them separately. Additional information regarding the location of the ASC can be found on
the USCIS web site at www.USCIS.gov.
Once the beneficiary has appeared at an ASC for biometrics capture, please return this notice to the
address indicated on this RFE.

On October 20, 2025, you, INNOVATIVE GLOBAL TALENT AGENCY LLC (petitioner), filed a
petition with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), seeking O-1A nonimmigrant
classification for MARLEN AUGUSTA LORBERG LIJERON (beneficiary) to work as World Class.
The O-1A classification applies to individuals with extraordinary ability in the sciences, education,
business, or athletics.  The individual must have sustained national or international acclaim.  The
individual's achievements must be in the field of expertise and show that the individual is one of the
small percentage who have risen to the very top of the field.  The individual must plan to continue to
work in the area of extraordinary ability.
To process your petition and determine if the beneficiary is eligible, additional information is
required.  This request provides suggested evidence that you may submit to satisfy each requested
item.  You may:
Submit one, some, or all of these items. 
Submit none of the suggested items and instead submit other evidence to satisfy the request. 
Explain how the evidence in the record already establishes eligibility.
Request a decision based on the record. 
Note, however, that you are responsible for providing evidence that best shows all requirements. 
Evidence must show eligibility for the requested benefit when you filed the petition.
Evidence of Sustained National or International Acclaim
You must show that the beneficiary has sustained national or international acclaim and recognition for
achievements in the field of expertise.  To demonstrate this, you may submit documentation to show
the beneficiary received a major, internationally recognized award, such as the Nobel Prize. 
Alternatively, you may show that the beneficiary satisfies at least three of the eight criteria discussed
below.  Ultimately, the totality of the evidence must establish that the beneficiary has sustained
national or international acclaim and that the beneficiary’s level of expertise indicates that the
beneficiary is one of that small percentage who has risen to the very top of the field.
Evidence of a Major, Internationally Recognized Award
You did not submit evidence for this option.  You may still submit evidence to satisfy it. 
Evidence that could help to determine that the award is major and internationally recognized may
show:
The award is internationally recognized as one of the top awards for the field;
The criteria used to grant the award;
The significance of the award in the field;
The reputation of the organization or the panel granting the award; 
Previous winners of the award who held international acclaim at the time of receiving
the award; or
How the award attracts competition from internationally recognized individuals in the
field.
Alternatively, you may attempt to qualify the beneficiary by providing evidence to satisfy at least
three of the criteria below.
Qualifying Criteria.  If you choose not to submit evidence of a one-time award, you may submit
CSCI129CSCI120000363574962 of 9www.uscis.gov
USCIS encourages you to sign up for a USCIS online account. To learn more about creating an account and the benefits, go to https://www.uscis.gov/file-online.

documentation of at least three of the criteria in this section.
The beneficiary does not appear to satisfy at least three of the eight criteria. You may still submit
evidence to satisfy criteria in this section. 
Awards: You may submit evidence showing the beneficiary received nationally or internationally
recognized prizes or awards for excellence in the field.  These are awards that do not meet the level of
a major, internationally recognized award that would satisfy that alternate requirement.
The beneficiary appears to have met this criterion.
Memberships in Associations: You may submit evidence showing the beneficiary belongs to
associations requiring outstanding achievements.  The achievements must be judged by recognized
national or international experts in relevant disciplines or fields.
In order to demonstrate that membership in an association meets this criterion, a petitioner must show
that the association requires outstanding achievements as an essential condition for admission to
membership. 
The evidence you submitted is insufficient.  You submitted the following to indicate that the
beneficiary meets this criterion:
Bolivian National Team member
Departmental Gymnastics Association of Santa Cruz
An Invitation to train under Brazilian National Coach Anita Klemann
USCIS has reviewed all of the material and is unable to determine that the membership in these groups
require outstanding achievements as an essential condition for membership.  
In regards to being on the Bolivian National Team, the record establishes that the beneficiary is a
member of the Bolivian National Team; however, the record does not establish that the members on
this team are members of any particular association.  Because the record does not address any
particular association, it does not establish that the beneficiary is a member of an association in the
field for which classification is sought.  Furthermore, you did not submit the requirements or criteria
used for membership of the Bolivian National Team.  Therefore, the record does not satisfy the
criterion. 
You also submitted a letter written by Silvia Yaneth Vasquez Pinedo (President of the Departmental
Gymnastics Association of Santa Cruz).  In part she writes: "The Departmental Gymnastics
Association of Santa Cruz certifies that Ms. Marlen Augusta Lorberg Lijeron is currently affiliated
with the Famiana Abastoflor Numberg FAN Rhythmic Gymnastics Training Center, which is part of
our association and is located in Santa Cruz de la Sierra, Bolivia."  While Ms. Vasquez Pinedo attests
that the beneficiary is affiliated with the training center, there is no indication in the record that being
affiliated with the training center constitutes membership in the association.   Furthermore, you did not
submit the requirements or criteria used for joining the Rhythmic Gymnastics Training Center.  
In regards to the invitation to train under Brazilian National Coach Anita Klemann, her letter states in
part: "Ms. Lorberg was invited to join our training program based on her athletic merits.  Throughout
her time with us, she participated in high-performance training sessions alongside Brazilian national
team athletes."  As stated above in the first point, because the record does not address any particular
association, it does not establish that the beneficiary is a member of an association in the field for
which classification is sought. Furthermore, you did not submit the requirements or criteria used to

For the reasons discussed above, the evidence submitted here does not show that the beneficiary has a
membership in as association that satisfies all elements of the criterion. 
You may still submit evidence to satisfy this criterion.
Evidence may include, but is not limited to, documentation showing:
The minimum requirements and criteria used to accept a person for the level

Evidence of recognized national or international experts who make

The beneficiary appears to have met this criterion.
Judging the Work of Others: You may submit evidence showing the beneficiary has participated as

field of specialization or in an allied field.
You did not submit evidence for this criterion.  You may still submit evidence to satisfy it
Evidence may include, but is not limited to, evidence that the beneficiary has been a:
Reviewer of abstracts or papers submitted for presentation at scholarly
conferences in the respective field;
Peer reviewer for scholarly publications;
Member of doctoral dissertation committees; or
Peer reviewer for government research funding programs.
Original Contributions: You may submit evidence showing the beneficiary made original

The evidence you submitted is insufficient.  In support of this criterion you submitted the following:
Her 2007 Gold medal redefined Bolivia's international status, inspiring national funding and

Mentorship and Talent Development Letter written by Fabiana Abastoflor
Sports media advocacy Letter written by Roberto Acosta Echavarria
Educational impact 
Regarding the testimonial letters written by Fabiana Abastoflor and Roberto Acosta: 
Fabiana Abastoflor states in part in her letter: "Marlen and I have know each other for over 15 years.

I-129:
The issue to be discussed is whether the I-129 is properly signed in accordance with
regulations, the I-129 instructions, and USCIS policy.
Title 8, Code of Federal Regulations (8CFR) 103.2(a)(2) prescribes the requirements for
signatures on filing, in pertinent part:
CSCI129CSCI120000363574967 of 9www.uscis.gov
USCIS encourages you to sign up for a USCIS online account. To learn more about creating an account and the benefits, go to https://www.uscis.gov/file-online.

signatures on filing, in pertinent part:
Signature. An applicant or petitioner must sign his or her benefit request...By signing the
benefit request, the applicant or petitioner...certifies under penalty of perjury that the benefit
request, and all evidence submitted with it, either at the time of filing or thereafter, is true and
correct.  Unless otherwise specified in this chapter, and acceptable signature on a benefit
request that is being filed with the USCIS si one that is either handwritten or, for benefit
requests filed electronically as permitted by the instructions to the form, in electronic format. 
The regulations require that the signature on an application,petition, or request submitted on
paper be handwritten and executed by an authorized signer with the power to bind the
petitioner.  Therefore, a valid signature consists of any handwritten mark or sign made by an
individual, but it does not include signatures created by a typewriter, word processor, stamp,
auto-pen, or similar device.  
The present form was not filed electronically, Therefore, the signatures on the present form
must be handwritten signatures.  
The Form I-129 instructions (Rev. 01/20/2025) further state the following regarding
signatures on a Form I-129:
Signature. You (or your signing authority) must properly complete your petition. USCIS
will not accept a stamped or typewritten name in place of any signature on this petition. If
you are under 14 years of age, your parent or legal guardian may sign the petition on your
behalf. A legal guardian may also sign for a mentally incompetent person. If your petition
is not signed, or if the signature is not valid, we will reject your petition. See 8 CFR
103.2(a)(7)(ii)(A). If USCIS accepts a request for adjudication and determines that it has a
deficient signature, USCIS may deny the request.
Validity of Signatures. USCIS will consider a photocopied, faxed, or scanned copy of an
original handwritten signature as valid for filing purposes. The photocopy, fax, or scan
must be of the original document containing the handwritten ink signature.
On Page 30 of your submitted I-129 Section 2. Statement by the Petitioner is missing the
signature.  Therefore, you must submit the original Form I-129 that contains the original
handwritten ink signatures to establish that you provided a photocopy, fax, or scan of the
Form I-129 that contained original handwritten ink signatures.

 P-1A Individual Athletes and Athletic Teams
You, Innovative Global Talent Agency, filed Form I-129, Petition for Nonimmigrant Worker, seeking
P-1A nonimmigrant classification for Bella Schneider da Costa.  You are seeking to employ or
sponsor the beneficiary as a World Class Trick Rider. 
The P-1A classification may be granted to internationally recognized athletes based on their
reputations and achievements as individuals.  It may also be granted to groups of two or more
individuals that function as a unit and are internationally recognized as teams.  Beneficiaries must be
coming to the United States to perform services requiring an internationally recognized athlete or team
at a specific athletic competition, as an athlete or team.

Prior Approvals
USCIS acknowledges that the beneficiary has previously been granted the benefit being sought, that
you are requesting to extend your petition, and have requested USCIS grant deference to prior
approvals when evaluating the beneficiary's eligibility for the benefit being sought.  When
adjudicating a subsequent petition or application involving the same parties and the same underlying
facts, where appropriate, USCIS will generally defer to its prior determination of eligibility for the
particular nonimmigrant classification sought.
However, each petition filing is a separate proceeding with a separate record.  Despite any previously
approved petitions, the petitioner bears the burden to establish eligibility for each petition that it
submits, and an immigration benefit cannot be granted when the petitioner fails to meet its burden of
proof for the petition it files, including an extension petition. See INA § 291.  USCIS is not required to
approve petitions where eligibility has not been demonstrated, merely because of prior approvals
which may have been erroneous.  Matter of Church Scientology International, 19 I&N Dec. 593, 597
(Comm'r 1988).
USCIS will not defer to prior approvals where:
There was a material error with regard to the previous approval(s);  1.
There has been a material change in circumstances or eligibility requirements; or  2.
There is new material information that adversely impacts the petitioner’s, beneficiary’s, or
applicant’s eligibility.

(E) Agents as petitioners. A United States agent may file a petition in cases involving workers
who are traditionally self-employed or workers who use agents to arrange short-term
employment on their behalf with numerous employers, and in cases where a foreign employer
authorizes the agent to act on its behalf. A United States agent may be: the actual employer of
the beneficiary; the representative of both the employer and the beneficiary; or, a person or
entity authorized by the employer to act for, or in place of, the employer as its agent. A petition
filed by an United States agent is subject to the following conditions:
(1) An agent performing the function of an employer must specify the wage offered and
the other terms and conditions of employment by contractual agreement with the
beneficiary or beneficiaries. The agent/employer must also provide an itinerary of
definite employment and information on any other services planned for the period of
time requested.
(2) A person or company in business as an agent may file the P petition involving
multiple employers as the representative of both the employers and the beneficiary or
beneficiaries if the supporting documentation includes a complete itinerary of services or
engagements. The itinerary shall specify the dates of each service or engagement, the
names and addresses of the actual employers, the names and addresses of the
establishment, venues, or locations where the services will be performed. In questionable
cases, a contract between the employer(s) and the beneficiary or beneficiaries may be
required. The burden is on the agent to explain the terms and conditions of the
employment and to provide any required documentation.
(3) A foreign employer who, through a United States agent, files a petition for a P
nonimmigrant alien is responsible for complying with all of the employer sanctions
provisions of section 274A of the Act and 8 CFR part 274a.

Requirements for Athletes and Teams
Beneficiaries may obtain P-1A classification by:
International recognition as an individual athlete or member of a team;
Being classified as a professional athlete;
Performing as an athlete or coach with a U.S. team in a foreign league; or
Performing individually or as part of a group in a theatrical ice skating production.
To satisfy this requirement, you submitted:
A petition support letter;
A "Petitioner Talent Agreement";
Testimonial letters;
Copies of articles about rodeos;
Printouts from websites;
Promotional material; and
Copies of articles about the beneficiary.
Beneficiary Qualifications
You indicate the beneficiary qualifies for P-1 non-immigrant status.  As defined in statute and
regulation, a beneficiary may qualify for the P-1A classification as an internationally recognized
athlete, a professional athlete, an amateur athlete, or as a professional or amateur skater who performs
individually or as part of a group in a theatrical ice skating production.  
As you do not claim the beneficiary qualifies as a professional athlete, an amateur athlete, a
professional or amateur skater who performs individually or as a part of a group in a theatrical ice
skating production, these grounds of eligibility will not be discussed further in this request. 
Internationally Recognized Athlete or Team
A beneficiary may qualify as a P-1A internationally recognized athlete if the beneficiary performs as
an athlete, individually or as part of a group or team, at an internationally recognized level of
performance and seeks to enter the United States temporarily for the purpose of performing as such an
athlete with respect to a specific athletic competition. Specifically, the P-1A must be coming to
perform services which require an internationally recognized athlete or team. 
Internationally recognized means having a high level of achievement in a field evidenced by a degree
of skill and recognition substantially above that ordinarily encountered, to the extent that such
achievement is renowned, leading, or well-known in more than one country.
Solely Competing
In order to be eligible for the P-1A classification, the beneficiary must be coming to the United States 
solely for the purpose of performing in a specific athletic competition as an athlete or coach, as
applicable.  Alternatively, athletes coming to the United States to perform in theatrical ice skating
productions must be coming solely to perform in specific ice skating productions or tours.  Permissible
activities also include short vacations, promotional appearances for the petitioning employer relating to
the competition, event or performance, and stopovers which are incidental and/or related to the
activity.

Tendered Contract
The evidence in the record must include a tendered contract with a major United States sports league
or team, or a tendered contract in an individual sport commensurate with international recognition in
that sport, if such contracts are normally executed in the sport.
The evidence you submitted is insufficient. 
On March 26, 2021, USCIS issued policy guidance concerning P-1A internationally recognized
athletes, and clarified:
USCIS interprets "major United States sports league" as a league that has a distinguished
reputation that is commensurate with an internationally recognized level of performance, and
"major United States sports team" as a team that participates in such a league, consistent
with the statutory standard for internationally recognized athletes."
You submitted no contracts with the organizing bodies or official invites to any of the events listed in
the itinerary.  Further, the record is absent supporting documentation about the events listed on the
itinerary that would establish the events' status as internationally recognized events and are considered
major United States sports leagues.
